<h1>Amos Quakes</h1>

<h2>~760 BCE</h2>
<h2>by Jefferson Williams </h2>

<hr>

<nav>
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/">Catalog<br>Home</a>
<a href="#startI">Introduction<br>& Summary</a>
<a href="#startT">Textual<br>Evidence</a>
<a href="#startA">Archaeoseismic<br>Evidence</a>
<a href="#startLs">Landslide<br>Evidence</a>
<a href="#startTs">Tsunamogenic<br>Evidence</a>
<a href="#startP">Paleoseismic<br>Evidence</a>
<a href="#startN">Notes<br>&nbsp;</a>
<a href="#startD">Paleoclimate<br>Droughts</a>

</nav><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>

<h3 id="startI">Introduction & Summary</h3>

UNDER CONSTRUCTION<br><br>

The Amos Quake appears to have been subject to legendary accretion. The earliest account from ~760 BCE comes from the first verse of the Book of Amos which describes this prophetic book as
<blockquote>
The words of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amos_(prophet)">Amos</a>, one of the shepherds of <a href="https://bibleatlas.org/tekoa.htm">Tekoa</a> — the vision he saw concerning Israel two years before the earthquake,
when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah">Judah</a> and
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam (II)</a> son of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jehoash_of_Israel">Jehoash</a>
<abbr Title="Hebrew Joash, a variant of Jehoash">[a]</abbr> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)">Israel</a>
</blockquote>

Although the
specification of the Kings provides chronological information, there is no description of seismic effects associated with the earthquake or localities affected.
As noted by <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>
and others, this earthquake may have initiated (or enhanced) a belief in seismic theophany -
that God expresses himself through earthquakes (see some examples in <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AmosQuakes.html#startN">Notes</a>). Later prophetic accounts in the Hebrew
Bible frequently mention earthquakes. One such account by Zechariah<sup>1</sup> prophesied about the
"<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Day_of_the_Lord">Day of the Lord</a>" and mentions that <q>you will flee as you fled from the earthquake
in the days of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> king of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah">Judah</a></q>.
This appears to reference the same earthquake mentioned in Amos and it adds a location - Jerusalem. Other text adjacent to this passage mentions a cleaving of the Mount of Olives
which created a valley from which people would flee Jerusalem. Although this is ostensibly about a time in the future which precedes
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Last_Judgment">Judgment Day</a>, one is left wondering whether it
contains echoes of seismic effects (e.g. a landslide on the Mount of Olives) recounted in oral or written lore which
fed the imagination of the author of this section of Zechariah. About 850 years later (in ~95 CE), Josephus, without
citing a source, wrote an expansive account about the Amos Quake telling a tale where King <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> decided to offer
incense to God upon the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altar_(Bible)#Altar_of_incense">golden altar</a> of the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solomon%27s_Temple">First Temple</a> in Jerusalem. When the Temple
Priesthood objected to this transgression, he threatened to kill them. At the same time <q>a great earthquake shook the ground and a rent was made in the temple, and the bright rays
of the sun shone through it, and fell upon the king's face, insomuch that the leprosy seized upon him immediately.</q> <a href="https://mechon-mametheim re.org/p/pt/pt09b15.htm#5">2 Kings 15:5</a>,
thought to have been written in two editions in the late 7th century BCE and mid-late 6th century BCE (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Books_of_Kings#cite_note-Fretheim-2">wikipedia citing
Fretheim , 1997:7 and Grabbe, 2016</a>) mentions that King Uzziah was afflicted by leprosy but does not add any of the narrative details of Josephus.
<a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt25b26.htm#19">2 Chronicles 19:19</a>, perhaps <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Books_of_Chronicles#Origins">written in the 5th century BCE</a> and
sometimes using Kings as source material, recounts all of the elements of Josephus except for the earthquake. Josephus goes on to describe a long runout landslide
at Eroge (likely <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">Ein Rogel</a>) associated with the earthquake. Later authors such as Avot de-Rabbi Nathan, perhaps originally composed
between the 1st and 3rd centuries CE (<a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Fathers_According_to_Rabbi_Nathan/YXgPAQAAIAAJ?hl=enl">Goldin, 1995:xxi</a>) and Jerome,
writing in 406 CE, repeat the essential elements of Josephus' account - minus the landslide at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">Ein Rogel</a>.<br><br>

By associating the earthquake and leprosy with King Uzziah's transgression against the Temple Priesthood, Josephus was reiterating one of the thematic cores of the Hebrew Bible - that when the
Kings and people of Judah and Israel followed the prescripts of Jewish Law, they were protected by God and when they disobeyed they were punished. If one strips
this element away, we may be left with an earthquake which struck Jerusalem creating landslides, some Temple damage, and other destruction.<br><br>

If we use <a href="https://archive.org/details/mysteriousnumber0000thie">Thiele (1983)'s</a> widely accepted chronology of the Kings,
the Amos Quake struck between 766/765 and 751 BCE. <a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_in_the/5TZXAQAAQBAJ?hl=en">
Schoors (2013:115)</a> noted that the Amos Quake <q>cannot be precisely dated (sometime around 760)</q>. A more precise date requires that we assume that
Josephus' chronologically suspect synchronisms are correct.
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>,
assuming that Josephus' synchronisms are reliable, dated the Amos Quake to the evening of 11 October 759 BCE. This was based
on a reasonable supposition that the story of Uzziah and the incense offering would have been meant to take place on 14 Tishrei; the eve
before the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a> which was the paramount holiday during
the First Temple period. How <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>
or anyone else came up with a year of 759 BCE is not clear as it is not specified in Amos 1:2 or any other source.
It is possible that this date was suggested due to an assumed allusion in <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.8.10?lang=bi">Amos 8:9</a>
to a solar eclipse that occurred in June 762 BCE<sup>2</sup>. <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>
also assumed that Josephus' account was reliable but came up with a year of 750 BCE.
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>'s
and <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>'s
dates appear to be flawed as they do not account for the full uncertainty associated with this event.<br><br>

The Amos quake may be part of a couplet of earthquakes separated in time by up to several decades; a discovery made by
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/230701697_Intrabasin_paleoearthquake_and_quiescence_correlation_of_the_late_Holocene_Dead_Sea">Kagan et. al. (2011)</a> who observed two seismites
in the mid eighth century BC at three paleoseismic sites in the Dead Sea; each separated by a few decades. The Archaeologic site of Deir Alla
also shows evidence for two earthquakes with some period of time passing between the two events. This could explain why the sometimes ambiguous
archeoseismic evidence shows destruction in northern and southern sites of what is now Israel, Palestine, and Jordan. Prior to understanding
that a pair of earthquakes could have been involved,
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a> and
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>,
assuming one large event, estimated Magnitudes of 7.3 and 8.0 respectively placing the epicenter in Northern Israel
(<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem, 1991</a>)
or southern Lebanon (<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al., 2000</a>).
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/Ambraseys2009.html">Ambraseys (2009)</a>, who was also
unaware that two earthquakes may have taken place, suggested that textual and archeological evidence for the magnitude of this
earthquake appeared to be over stated.<br><br>

Earthquake couplets appear to be a characteristic of the Dead Sea transform where one earthquake triggers a second one.
The time span between the first and second earthquake can be from hours to decades. Examples include

<ul>
<li>The <a href="http://www.deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/DeadFishAndSoldiersQuake.html">Dead Fish and Soldiers Quake(s)</a> in the middle of the 2nd century BCE</li>
<li>The <a href="http://www.deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CyrilQuakes.html">Cyril Quakes</a> of May 18 and May 19 363 CE (6 hours apart)</li>
<li>The <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/1202CEQuake.html">1202 CE</a> and <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/1212CEQuake.html">1212 CE</a> Quakes</li>
<li>The <a href="http://www.deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/SabbaticalYearQuakes.html">Sabbatical Year Quakes</a> in mid January of 749 CE (probably less than 17 hours apart)</li>
<li>The <a href="http://www.deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/1759CEBaalbeAndSafedQuakes.html">1759 CE Baalbek and Safed Quakes</a> (about a month apart)</li>
<li>The <a href="http://www.deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/1834CEFellahinRevoltQuake.html">1834 CE Fellahin Revolt Quake</a> and the
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/1837CESafedQuake.html">1837 CE Safed Quake</a></li>
</ul>



<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

1 <a href="https://archive.org/details/introductiontool0000long/page/488/mode/2up">Longman and Dillard (1994:489)</a>
note that there is no consensus scholarship on the date when Chapters 9-14 of Zechariah were composed.

<blockquote>
... the consensus among critical scholars has been that chapters 9– 14 are from a different author
or authors than chapters 1– 8. However, beyond this assertion there is little unanimity. A bewildering variety
of dates and settings have been proposed for the second half of the book, ranging from the eighth century BC to the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maccabees">Maccabean period</a> [167 - 37 BCE].
</blockquote>

2 See Notes in the Ben-Menahem (1991) section in <a href="#DatingFromTheTexts">Dating from Textual Sources</a>.<br><br>


</p>
</div>
</div>



<div style="padding:10px;">


<h3 id="startT">Textual Evidence</h3>
<table id="Textual" class="wrappingarcheotable" style="width:100%; white-space:normal;">

<thead>
<tr>
<th>Text (with hotlink)</th>
<th>Original Language</th>
<th>Biographical Info</th>
<th>Religion</th>
<th>Date of Composition</th>
<th>Location Composed</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><a href="#DamageReports">Damage Reports from Textual Sources</a></td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#DatingFromTheTexts">Dating from Textual Sources</a></td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>The first line of the Book of Amos specifies that Amos prophesied while
King <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> ruled <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah">Judah</a> and
King <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam (II)</a> ruled <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)">Israel</a>
and the earthquake struck two years later. If we use <a href="https://archive.org/details/mysteriousnumber0000thie">Thiele (1983)'s</a> widely accepted chronology of the Kings,
the Amos Quake struck between 766/765 and 751 BCE. <a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_in_the/5TZXAQAAQBAJ?hl=en">
Schoors (2013:115)</a> noted that the Amos Quake <q>cannot be precisely dated (sometime around 760)</q>.<br><br>

A more precise date requires that we assume that Josephus' chronologically suspect synchronisms written about ~850 years after the event are correct.
Josephus states that when King <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> tried to burn incense in the Temple, an earthquake damaged the
Temple and he was struck with leprosy or leprosy was first recognized on him.
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>,
assuming that Josephus' synchronisms are reliable, dated the Amos Quake to the evening of 11 October 759 BCE. This was based
on a reasonable supposition that the story of Uzziah and the incense would have been meant to take place on 14 Tishrei, the eve
before the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a> which was the paramount holiday during
the First Temple period. How <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>
or anyone else came up with a year of 759 BCE is not clear as it is not specified in Amos 1:2 or any other source.
It is possible, this date was suggested due to an assumed allusion in <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.8.10?lang=bi">Amos 8:9</a>
to a solar eclipse that occurred in June 762 BCE.
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>
also assumed that Josephus' account was reliable but came up with a year of 750 BCE.
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>'s
and <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>'s
dates appear to be flawed as they do not account for the full uncertainty associated with this event. Josephus' uncited and chronologically suspect synchronisms
cannot be relied on with certainty.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><a href="#Amos">Amos</a></td>
<td>Hebrew</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>
<td>Jewish</td>
<td><a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Minor_Prophets/iwfxywEACAAJ?hl=en">
Niehaus in McComiskey (2020:316-317)</a> suggest that <q>it is likely that [Amos] prophesied
late in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam [II]</a>'s reign, perhaps in the early 760s.</q></td>
<td>not entirely known - <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bethel">Bethel</a> and perhaps other locations in the northern Kingdom such as
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samaria_(ancient_city)">Samaria</a></td>
<td>Using Thiele's chronology, the first line of the Book of Amos
dates the earthquake to between 766/765 and 751 BCE. No seismic effects or locations were specified.<br><br>
<a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos%201&version=NIV">Amos 1:1</a>
- <q>The words of Amos, one of the shepherds of <a href="https://bibleatlas.org/tekoa.htm">Tekoa</a>
— the vision he saw concerning Israel two years before the earthquake,
when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah">Judah</a> and
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam (II)</a> son of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jehoash_of_Israel">Jehoash</a>
<abbr Title="Hebrew Joash, a variant of Jehoash">[a]</abbr> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)">Israel</a></q>.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Zechariah">Zechariah</a></td>
<td>Hebrew</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Biography
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Zechariah.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Zechariah"></iframe>

</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>
<td>Jewish</td>
<td>unknown - <a href="https://archive.org/details/introductiontool0000long/page/488/mode/2up">
Longman and Dillard (1994:489)</a> note that estimates for the date of the likely anonymous composition of Zechariah 14
vary from the 8th century BCE to the Maccabean period </td>
<td>unknown</td>
<td>In Zechariah 14:5, a prophetic passage likely written by an unknown author at an unknown date about the
"Day of the Lord" mentions that <q>you will flee as you fled from the earthquake
<abbr Title="Or 5 My mountain valley will be blocked and will extend to Azel. It will be blocked as it was blocked because of the earthquake">[a]</abbr>
in the days of Uzziah king of Judah.</q> Using Thiele's chronology, this dates this earthquake to between 768/767 and
751/750 BCE. The previous sentence (Zechariah 14:4) refers to a prophetic splitting of the Mount of Olives;
creating a valley between northern and southern parts of the Mount. The valley is said to extend to Azel; an unknown location
presumably in the vicinity of Jerusalem. This description of a seismic effect on the Mount of Olives could echo previous oral or written
reports of landslides on the Mount of Olives during one of the Amos Quakes.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#IsaiahAnd Targum">Isaiah and Targumn Isaiah</a></td>
<td>Isaiah - Hebrew<br>Targum Isaiah - Aramaic</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Biography - Isaiah
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Isaiah.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Isaiah"></iframe>
</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Background - Targum Isaiah
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/IsaiahTargum.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="IsaiahTargum"></iframe>
</p>
</div>
</div>

</td>
<td>Jewish</td>
<td>Isaiah - Ch. 1-39 date to 738-687 BCE<br>Targum Isaiah - between ~100 and ~300 CE (multiple authors)</td>
<td>Isaiah - Judea and Samaria ?<br>Targum Isaiah - Palestine and Babylon (multiple authors)</td>
<td>Targum Isaiah 28:21 explains or interprets a cryptic passage in Isaiah 28:21 by stating that
<q>the mountains shook when the glory of the Lord was revealed in the days of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> the King</q>.
Using Thiele's chronology, this dates this earthquake to between 768/767 and 751/750 BCE.
<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.9.8?lang=bi">Isaiah 9:8</a> appears to describe damage to buildings and fallen trees in Samaria which was due to the Amos Quake.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Josephus">Josephus</a></td>
<td>Greek, possibly translated from an earlier version in Aramaic</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Biography
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Josephus.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Josephus"></iframe>
</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>
<td>Jewish</td>
<td>about 95 CE</td>
<td>Rome and ?</td>
<td>In a chronologically suspect passage, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephus">Josephus</a>
synchronizes the earthquake with an incident when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a>
(of Judah) <abbr Title="when a remarkable day was come, and a general festival was to be celebrated">put on a holy garment and burned incense at the Temple</abbr>
and, in turn, was afflicted with leprosy and experienced an earthquake
which "rents" (cracks) the Temple. Using Thiele's chronology, this equates to 750/751 BCE.
The reason that the passage is chronologically suspect is that by wearing the holy garment and burning
incense at the Temple (in Jerusalem), Uzziah was usurping the duties and domain of the high Priest
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azariah_II">Azariah II</a>); thus incurring punishment from God
for his actions in the form of leprosy and an earthquake. Seismic effects from the earthquake include a cracking of the First Temple
in Jerusalem and possible landslides at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">Ein Rogel (near Jerusalem)</a>.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#AvotRabbiNathan">Avot de-Rabbi Nathan</a></td>
<td>Hebrew with a sprinkling of Aramaic along with Greek and Latin loan words</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Biography
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/AvotRabbiNathan.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="AvotRabbiNathan"></iframe>
</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>
<td>Jewish</td>
<td>probably between the 1st and 3rd centuries CE</td>
<td>probably Palestine</td>
<td>Like <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephus">Josephus</a>,
Avot de-Rabbi Nathan synchronizes the earthquake with an incident when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a>
(of Judah) burned incense at the Temple
and, in turn, was afflicted with leprosy and experienced an earthquake
which "rents" (cracks) the Temple. Using Thiele's chronology, this equates to 750/751 BCE.
The passage is chronologically suspect because by burning
incense at the Temple (in Jerusalem), Uzziah was usurping the duties and domain of the high Priest
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azariah_II">Azariah II</a>); thus incurring punishment from God
for his actions in the form of leprosy and an earthquake. A second version of this text (version B) recounts the incident of
King Uzziah burning incense at the Temple and getting afflicted by leprosy but does not mention an earthquake.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><a href="#MidrashTanchuma">Midrash Tanchuma</a></td>
<td>Hebrew</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Background
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Midrash.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Midrash"></iframe>
</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>
<td>Jewish</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/GuidoboniEtAl1994.html">Guidoboni et al (1994)</a> noted to
<q>See also <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanhuma">Midrash Tanhuma</a> to Noah, chapter 5</q>. Although Amos is quoted in version B
(aka Midrash Tanchuma Yelammedenu) of this text (<a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+2&version=NIV">Amos 2:6</a>), the part of Amos mentioning the earthquake is not quoted
and there does not seem to be any allusions to an earthquake. There is no mention of Amos or an earthquake in version A (aka Midrash Tanchuma Buber).</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><a href="#Jerome">Jerome</a></td>
<td>Latin</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Biography
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Jerome.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Jerome"></iframe>
</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>
<td>Christian</td>
<td>406 CE</td>
<td>Bethlehem</td>
<td>Like Josephus, Jerome's commentary synchronizes the earthquake with an incident when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a>
(of Judah) attempted to make sacrifices at the 1st Temple in Jerusalem and, in turn, was afflicted with leprosy
and experienced an earthquake. Using Thiele's chronology, this equates to 750/751 BCE. Although Jerome does not specifically
mention damage to the 1st Temple due to the earthquake, the context of the account indicates that the earthquake was experienced at the 1st Temple in Jerusalem.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#LegendsOfTheJews">Legends of the Jews</a></td>
<td>English translated from German</td>
<td>
<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
Background
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/LegendsOfTheJews.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Legends of the Jews"></iframe>
</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>
<td>Jewish</td>
<td>1909 CE</td>
<td>New York City (USA)</td>
<td>Like Josephus, <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">Ginzberg (1936:262)</a> synchronizes the earthquake
with an incident when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> (of Judah) attempted to make
sacrifices at the 1st Temple in Jerusalem and, in turn, was afflicted with leprosy and experienced an earthquake. Using Thiele's chronology,
this equates to 750/751 BCE. Seismic effects from the earthquake include a cracking of the First Temple in Jerusalem and a landslide.
Although <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">Austin et al (2000:663)</a> state that
<q>details of the earthquake and landslide, as described by Josephus, are independently supported by
very old traditions of the rabbis (Ginzberg, 1936, p. 262)</q>, <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">Ginzberg (1936:262)</a>'s sources are a complicated mix of Rabbinic and other sources
and include Josephus and Avot de Rabbi Nathan (Traditional Version A).<a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">Ginzberg (1936:262)</a>'s "seismic" source does not appear be independent from
Josephus and the text by Ginzberg describing seismic effects are essentially identical to Josephus' account.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>

</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="DamageReports">Damage Reports from Textual Sources</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Seismic Effects</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

´

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">
<caption><b>Seismic Effects</b></caption>

<tr>
<th>Effect</th>
<th>Sources</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Earthquake</td>
<td>Amos 1:1, Zechariah 14:5, Josephus, Avot de-Rabbi Nathan, Jerome's Commentary on Amos, Legends of the Jews</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Landslide</td>
<td>Zechariah 14:4, Josephus, Legends of the Jews</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>Zechariah 14:4 is written as future prophecy concerning the "Day of the Lord" and describes a splitting of the Mount of Olives that could echo
oral and/or written traditions about landslides in the area due to one of the Amos Quakes</li>
<li>Josephus describes a long run-out landslide that took place at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">Ein Rogel</a> in
in Silwan on the outskirts of the border of what was then Jerusalem</li>
<li>Legends of the Jews is probably relying on Josephus</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1st Temple cracked</td>
<td>Josephus, Avot de-Rabbi Nathan, Legends of the Jews</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>Legends of the Jews is probably relying on Josephus</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Damage to buildings and fallen trees in Samaria</td>
<td>Isaiah 9:9</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>interpretation from the text</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Tsunami in the Sea of Galilee</td>
<td>Amos 5:8; 9:5-6</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem, 1991</a> states
that <q>a tsunami in the Sea of Galilee is hinted in Amos 5:8; 9:5-6.</q> however neither of these passages seems to be about the Amos Quake and refer instead
to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assyrian_captivity">destruction of Israel by the Neo-Assyrian Empire in 722 BCE</a>. See Possible Tsunami dropdown below for details</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</table>




<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Possible Tsunami</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.5.8?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en">Amos 5:8</a> reads as follows:

<blockquote>
Who made the Pleiades and Orion,<br>
Who turns deep darkness into dawn<br>
And darkens day into night,<br>
Who summons the waters of the sea<br>
And pours them out upon the earth—<br>
His name is the LORD!
</blockquote>

<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.5?lang=bi">Amos Chapter 5</a> is a prophecy about the destruction of Israel.<br><br>

<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.9.5?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en">Amos 9:5-6</a> reads as follows:

<blockquote>
5 It is my Lord the GOD of Hosts<br>
At whose touch the earth trembles<br>
And all who dwell on it mourn,<br>
And all of it swells like the Nile<br>
And subsides like the Nile of Egypt;<br><br>

6 Who built His chambers in heaven<br>
And founded His vault on the earth,<br>
Who summons the waters of the sea<br>
And pours them over the land—<br>
His name is the LORD.<br>

</blockquote>

<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.9?lang=bi">Amos Chapter 9</a> is a prophecy about the destruction and restoration of Israel. Amos 9:5-6 is in the section about the destruction
of Israel and appears to allude to the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assyrian_captivity">destruction of Israel by the Neo-Assyrian Empire in 722 BCE</a>.


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos Chapter 5 - English and Hebrew (sefaria - Masoretic text)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Chapter 5</li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.5?lang=bi">sefaria.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.5?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">

</div>

<div class="slidepanel">

</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.9?lang=bii#"

</p>

</div>



</p>
</div>
</div>





</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<td>Jerusalem</td>
<td>Zechariah 14:5, Josephus, Avot de-Rabbi Nathan, Jerome's Commentary on Amos, Legends of the Jews</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>Zechariah 14:4 implies that Zechariah 14:5 describes an earthquake that was experienced in Jerusalem</li>
<li>The context of the account from Jerome's Commentary on Amos indicates that an earthquake that was experienced in Jerusalem</li>
<li>Legends of the Jews is probably relying on Josephus</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Damage to buildings and fallen trees in Samaria</td>
<td>Isaiah 9:9</td>
<td>
<ul>

</ul>
</td>
</tr>


</table>

</p>
</div>
</div>



</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="DatingFromTheTexts">Dating from Textual Sources</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>


The first line of the Book of Amos specifies that Amos prophesied while
King <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> ruled <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah">Judah</a> and
King <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam (II)</a> ruled <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)">Israel</a>
and the earthquake struck two years later. If we use <a href="https://archive.org/details/mysteriousnumber0000thie">Thiele (1983)'s</a> widely accepted chronology of the Kings,
the Amos Quake struck between 766/765 and 751 BCE. <a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_in_the/5TZXAQAAQBAJ?hl=en">
Schoors (2013:115)</a> noted that the Amos Quake <q>cannot be precisely dated (sometime around 760)</q>.<br><br>

A more precise date requires that we assume that Josephus' chronologically suspect synchronisms written about ~850 years after the event are correct.
Josephus states that when King <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> tried to burn incense in the Temple, an earthquake damaged the
Temple and he was struck with leprosy or leprosy was first recognized on him.
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>,
assuming that Josephus' synchronisms are reliable, dated the Amos Quake to the evening of 11 October 759 BCE. This was based
on a reasonable supposition that the story of Uzziah and the incense would have been meant to take place on 14 Tishrei, the eve
before the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a> which was the paramount holiday during
the First Temple period. How <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>
or anyone else came up with a year of 759 BCE is not clear as it is not specified in Amos 1:2 or any other source.
It is possible, this date was suggested due to an assumed allusion in <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.8.10?lang=bi">Amos 8:9</a>
to a solar eclipse that occurred in June 762 BCE (see Notes at the bottom of the Ben-Menahem (1991) collapsible panel).
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>
also assumed that Josephus' account was reliable but came up with a year of 750 BCE.
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>'s
and <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>'s
dates appear to be flawed as they do not account for the full uncertainty associated with this event. Josephus' uncited and chronologically suspect synchronisms
cannot be relied on with certainty. Nevertheless, the historical exegeses of
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>
and <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a> have value as
hypotheses and explorations so their methodologies are shown in the collapsible panels below.<br><br>

The other Amos Quake (observed in paleoseismic sections of the Dead Sea) is undated but,
according to <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/230701697_Intrabasin_paleoearthquake_and_quiescence_correlation_of_the_late_Holocene_Dead_Sea">Kagan et. al. (2011)</a>,
struck within a few decades of the one that is written about.<br><br>



<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Ben-Menahem (1991)</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

</ul>

height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>

<div class="top expand">

</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Zechariah.14.1?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">


<tr>
<th>Date</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Evening of 11 Oct. 759 BCE</td>
<td><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem, 1991</a>
dates the Amos Quake to the evening of 11 October 759 BCE stating that the <q>day of occurrence, according to II Chron.26 and Josephus, is likely to be on the eve of the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a>, 14 Tishrei, 3003, which is October 759 B.C.E.</q></td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.sefaria.org/II_Chronicles.26?lang=bi">Chapter 26 of II Chronicles</a> contains the story about
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> offering incense
on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altar_(Bible)#Altar_of_incense">Golden Altar</a>
of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solomon%27s_Temple">First Temple</a> - a transgression against
the Temple Priests - and suffering leprosy as a result.</li>
<li>Josephus synchronizes this story with the Amos Quake</li>
<li><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>
interprets this text to suggest that the incense offering was on the eve of a holiday rather than on some random day. In fact, he suggests that it was
on the eve of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a> which was the most important holiday of the year
during the First Temple period.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctvzpv502.7">Rubenstein (1988:30)</a> notes that there is a scholarly consensus <q>that throughout the first temple
period the autumnal festival [i.e. the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a>] was the paramount Israelite celebration</q>.</li>
<li>Solomon dedicated the First Temple during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a>
(<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/I_Kings.8.2?lang=bi">1 Kings 8:2</a>)</li>
<li>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a> is celebrated from the 15th to the 21st day of Tishrei.</li>
<li>The eve of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a> would thus be on the 14th of Tishrei</li>
<li>In 759 BCE, 14 Tishrei 3003 in the Hebrew calendar fell on the 11th of October in the Julian Calendar
(calculated using <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Chronos/#Hebrew">CHRONOS</a>)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Zechariah.14.1?lang=bi">Chapter 14 of Zechariah</a> which is prophesying about the "Day of the Lord" and mentions
the Amos Quake in <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Zechariah.14.5?lang=bi">14:5</a>, mentions the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a>
in <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Zechariah.14.16?lang=bi">14:16-19</a></li>
<li>It is unclear how <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem, 1991</a> or
anyone else came up with a year of 759 CE for the Amos Quake which assumes that Amos produced his last prophesy in 761 CE. It is possible, this date was
suggested due to an assumed allusion in <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.8.10?lang=bi">Amos 8:9</a> to a solar eclipse that occurred in June 762 BCE. See Notes below.
If we use Theile's chronology, Jeroboam II and Uzziah were both ruling (as sole rulers) between the
years of 768/767 and 753 BCE. Since the earthquake was two years after a time when both men were ruling, this
leads to a time bracket of 766/765 - 751 BCE.</li>
<li>The story associating the onset of leprosy in King Uzziah when he burned incense at the Temple may be a forced synchronicity
reiterating one of the thematic cores of the Hebrew Bible which is that when the Kings and people of Judah and Israel followed the prescripts of Jewish Law (Halakha),
they were protected by God and when they disobeyed they were punished. Further, the earliest extant text which synchronizes this incense/leprosy
story with the Amos Quake is Josephus writing approximately 850 years after the earthquake.</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>


</table>


<h7>Online Versions and Further Reading</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctvzpv502">
Rubenstein, J. L. (2020). A History of Sukkot in the Second Temple and Rabbinic Periods, Brown Judaic Studies.</a> - open access at JSTOR<br><br>

<h7>Notes</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Ben-Menahem's (1991) reference to a solar eclipse
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">


<tr>
<th>Date</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>~759 or ~760 BCE</td>
<td><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>
stated that
<blockquote>
The date of this earthquake is linked to the eclipse of the Sun on June 15, 763 B.C.E. (Julian Day 1,442,902.8392, or Monday, Sivan 30, 2998, of the Jewish Calendar
[see Kudlek and Mickler, 1971; Chambers, 1904, Thompson, 1900; Oppolzer, 1887; Fotheringham, 1920]). The eclipse was partial in Jerusalem
(maximal magnitude 0.91). Evidence for the proximity of the earthquake and the eclipse is found in Amos 8:8-9; Zech. 14:4-7, and Jer. 4:24.
</blockquote>
</td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>It is not clear how the prophetic texts of <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.8.8?lang=bi">Amos 8:8-9</a>,
<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Zechariah.14.4?lang=bi">Zechariah 14:4-7</a>, or <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Jeremiah.4.24?lang=bi">Jerimiah 4:24</a>
are <q>evidence for the proximity of the earthquake and the eclipse</q></li>
<li>All three passages are prophesies which refer to calamities on a future date with poetic descriptions of darkness on the earth:

<ul>
<li>In Amos it says <q>I will darken the earth on a sunny day</q></li>
<li>In Zechariah it says <q>In that day, there shall be neither sunlight nor cold moonlight</q></li>
<li>In Jeremiah it says <q>I look ... at the skies and their light is gone</q></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Minor_Prophets/iwfxywEACAAJ?hl=en">
Niehaus in McComiskey (2020:316-317)</a> suggests that <q>it is likely that [Amos] prophesied
late in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam [II]</a>'s reign, perhaps in the early 760s</q></li>
<li>As the reference to darkness in Amos takes place in the 8th chapter of a 9 chapter book, it may
have been composed towards the end of his ministry and may have referred to a recently experienced solar eclipse; such as the one in
June 762 BCE (see below). If all of this is the case and the Amos Quake struck 2 years after Amos's ministry ended, this would date
the Amos Quake to around 759 or 760 BCE.</li>
<li>The following online eclipse catalogs list eclipses from around this time
<ul>
<li>total solar eclipse on 15 June 762 BCE (not 763 BCE) which would have been visible in Judah and Samaria - <a href="https://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/5MCSE/plate147.pdf">NASA</a></li>
<li>total solar eclipse on 7 June 762 BCE (not 763 BCE) which would have been visible in Judah and Samaria - <a href="https://ssp.imcce.fr/forms/solar-eclipses/-0762-06-07">imcee</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a> lists the following
references for the eclipse; all of which are likely less accurate than NASA and imcee. Neither NASA nor imcee show a solar eclipse which would have been visible in Judah
or the northern Kingdom in 763 BCE. Thus <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>'s
763 BCE date appears to have been a typographic error.
<ul>
<li>Chambers, G.F., The Story of Eclipses, McClure, Phillips, New York, 1904.</li>
<li>Fotheringham, J.K., A solution of ancient eclipses of the Sun, Mon. Not. R. Astron. Soc., 81, 104-126, 1920.</li>
<li>Kudlek, M., and E.H. Mickler, Solar and Lunar Eclipses of the Ancient Near East from 3000 B.C. to 0 With Maps, Butzon and Bercker Kevelaer, Berlin, Germany, 1971.</li>
<li>Oppolzer, T.R., Cannon Der Finsternisse, Denkschriften der Kaiserlichen Akademie der Wissenschafter, Wien, 1887.</li>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/reportsofmagicia07thomuoft">
Thompson, R.C., The Reports of the Magicians and Astrologers of Nineveh and Babylon in the British Museum, I-II, Luzac, London, 1900.</a></li>
</ul>
</li>

</ul>
</td>
</tr>


</table>





</p>
</div>
</div>





</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Austin et. al. (2000)</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Austin et. al. (2000)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000:664)</a></li>
</ul>



<div class="tooltipfullfoto"><img src="http://www.deadseaquake.info/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/Fig6_AustinEtAl2000.png"
alt="Fig. 6 Austin et al (2000)" width="100%">
<span class="tooltiptextfullfoto" >Fig. 6 - Time line showing the historical context and dating of Amos's earthquake.
Synchronisms, which are shown as vertical arrows under the time line, allow Amos's earthquake to be dated to 750 B.C.
The chronology of Hebrew kings follows Thiele (1983) with slight revisions by Finegan (1998).<br><br>
Sources for the synchronisms: <br>
<ul>
<li>S-1 is from <a href="https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0146%3Abook%3D9%3Awhiston+chapter%3D10%3Awhiston+section%3D4">
Josephus Antiquities IX:225</a> - see Notes</li>
<li>S-2 is from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/II_Kings.15.32?lang=bi">2 Kings 15:32</a> (<q>In the second year of Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel, Jotham son of King Uzziah of Judah began to reign</q>)</li>
<li>S-3 is from 2 Kings 15:27, 30</li>
<li>S-4 is from 2 Kings 15:30</li>
<li>S-5 is from Borger and Tadmor (1982)</li>
<li>S-6 is from 2 Kings 17:6</li>
<li>S-7 is from 2 Kings 15:8</li>
<li>S-8 is from 2 Kings 15:13</li>
<li>S-9 is from 2 Kings 15:17</li>
</ul> from Austin et. al. (2000)</span>
</div><br><br>

<b>The Date of Amos's Earthquake</b><br><br>

Figure 6 is a time line that allows Amos's earthquake to be dated. According to Josephus (Antiquities IX:225; Marcus, 1937),
the earthquake was associated with the events that caused King Uzziah's disability, requiring his son Jotham to become the
visible coregent in Jerusalem. The synchronism between the earthquake and Jotham's first year, as noted by Josephus,
is shown as a vertical arrow denoted "S-1" in Figure 6. Another important synchronism (2 Kings 15:30) links Jotham's
twentieth year as king of Judah and the accession of Hoshea as king of Israel (denoted "S-4" in Fig. 6). An Assyrian
inscription (Tadmor, 1994) describes how Hoshea, upon accession as king of Israel, delivered tribute payment to the Assyrian
king who, at that time, was personally conducting a military campaign against the Chaldean city of Sarrabani (synchronism denoted "S-5").
The Assyrian Eponym List (eclipse calibrated) allows the Assyrian siege of Sarrabani and Sapia to be dated to 731 B.C. (Borger and Tadmor, 1982; Tadmor, 1994).
Therefore, the accession of Hoshea falls between Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 732 and Nisan (Mar./Apr.) 731, and Jotham's twentieth year is 732/731 (Finegan, 1998, p. 250, 261).
The earthquake in Jotham's first year is dated to 750 B.C.<br><br>

These synchronisms, which establish the date of Amos's earthquake, provide the framework upon which the chronology of Hebrew kings can be superimposed.
This is done in Figure 6 assuming Thiele's chronology (Thiele, 1983; McFall, 1991; Finegan, 1998). The chronology of Thiele appears to work better
with the earthquake and associated synchronisms than chronologies with different assumptions. Yeivin (1979) and Na'aman (1986) dated Hoshea's
accession at 731/730, not 732/731. Therefore, they place Jotham's accession and the earthquake at 749 B.C. The Yeivin and Na'aman chronologies
supposedly follow Tadmor's analysis. However, Tadmor (1979, p. 54) argued for the accession of Hoshea in 732, not 731. Thus, Thiele's chronology
is better for the middle eighth century, and the earthquake should be dated to the year 750 B.C.

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Notes - excerpts from Josephus
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0146%3Abook%3D9%3Awhiston+chapter%3D10%3Awhiston+section%3D4">[222]</a> is from perseus</li>
<li>from Flavius Josephus. The Works of Flavius Josephus. Translated by. William Whiston, A.M. Auburn and Buffalo. John E. Beardsley. 1895.</li>
</ul>


[222] While Uzziah was in this state, and making preparation [for futurity], he was corrupted in his mind by pride,
and became insolent, and this on account of that abundance which he had of things that will soon perish, and despised
that power which is of eternal duration (which consisted in piety towards God, and in the observation of the laws);
so he fell by occasion of the good success of his affairs, and was carried headlong into those sins of his father,
which the splendor of that prosperity he enjoyed, and the glorious actions he had done, led him into, while he was
not able to govern himself well about them. Accordingly, when a remarkable day was come, and a general festival was
to be celebrated, he put on the holy garment, and went into the temple to offer incense to God upon the golden altar,
which he was prohibited to do by Azariah the high priest, who had fourscore priests with him, and who told him that it
was not lawful for him to offer sacrifice, and that "none besides the posterity of Aaron were permitted so to do."
And when they cried out that he must go out of the temple, and not transgress against God, he was wroth at them,
and threatened to kill them, unless they would hold their peace. In the mean time a great earthquake shook the
ground<sup>1</sup> and a rent was made in the temple, and the bright rays of the sun shone through it, and fell upon
the king's face, insomuch that the leprosy seized upon him immediately. And before the city, at a place called Eroge,
half the mountain broke off from the rest on the west, and rolled itself four furlongs, and stood still at the east
mountain, till the roads, as well as the king's gardens, were spoiled by the obstruction. Now, as soon as the priests
saw that the king's face was infected with the leprosy, they told him of the calamity he was under, and commanded
that he should go out of the city as a polluted person. Hereupon he was so confounded at the sad distemper, and
sensible that he was not at liberty to contradict, that he did as he was commanded, and underwent this miserable
and terrible punishment for an intention beyond what befitted a man to have, and for that impiety against God which
was implied therein. So he abode out of the city for some time, and lived a private life, while his son Jotham took
government; after which he died with grief and anxiety at what had happened to him, when he had lived sixty-eight years,
and reigned of them fifty-two; and was buried by himself in his own gardens.


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


1 This account of an earthquake at Jerusalem at the very same time when Uzziah usurped the priest's office,
and went into the sanctuary to burn incense, and of the consequences of the earthquake, is entirely
wanting in our other copies, though it be exceeding like to a prophecy of Jeremiah, now in Zechariah 14:4, 5;
in which prophecy mention is made of "fleeing from that earthquake, as they fled from this earthquake in the
days of Uzziah king of Judah;" so that there seems to have been some considerable resemblance between these
historical and prophetical earthquakes.



</p>
</div>
</div>

</p>
</div>
</div>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">


<tr>
<th>Date</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>750 BCE</td>
<td></td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>Like <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>,
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a> assumes that
Josephus' synchronisms are correct</li><br>
<li>This dates the earthquake to the same time that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a>
began to co-rule Judea with his father <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a>.</li><br>
<li><a href="https://www.sefaria.org/II_Kings.15.30?lang=bi">2 Kings 15:32</a> states that
<blockquote>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoshea">Hoshea</a> son of Elah conspired against
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pekah">Pekah</a> son of Remaliah, attacked him, and killed him.
He succeeded him as king in the twentieth year of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a> son of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a>.
</blockquote>
</li>
<li><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a> date the
20th year of Jotham's rule to between Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 732 BCE and Nisan (Mar./Apr.) 731 BCE. This date was determined as follows:</li><br>
<ul>

<li><q>An Assyrian inscription describes how <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoshea">Hoshea</a>, upon accession as king of Israel, delivered tribute payment to the
Assyrian king [<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiglath-Pileser_III">Tiglath-Pileser III (r. 745-727 BCE)</a>] who,
at that time, was personally conducting a military campaign against the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaldea">Chaldean</a> city of Sarrabani</q>
(JW: This is in Tadmor (1994) which I am currently unable to access. I did access another book of Assyrian inscriptions by
<a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/105/mode/2up">
Tadmor and Yamada (2011)</a> which contains multiple descriptions of the accession of Hoshea and the seige of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaldea">Chaldean</a> city of Sarrabani although this may not be what was referenced in
Tadmor (1994). See the inscriptions in the collapsible panels beneath this chronology table.)</li><br>
<li><q>The <a href="https://www.livius.org/articles/concept/limmu/limmu-list-858-699-bce/.">Assyrian Eponym List</a>
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assyrian_eclipse">eclipse calibrated</a>) allows the Assyrian siege
of Sarrabani and Sapia to be dated to 731 B.C.</q></li><br>
<li>JW: the relevant entry from the <a href="https://www.livius.org/articles/concept/limmu/limmu-list-858-699-bce/.">Assyrian Eponym List</a> (aka the Limmu
list) is shown below:
<blockquote>
[731/730] During the eponomy of Nergal-uballit, the governor of Ahizu-hina, campaign against Šapiya.
</blockquote>
</li>

<li><q>Therefore, the accession of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoshea">Hoshea</a> falls between Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 732 and Nisan (Mar./Apr.) 731,
and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a>'s twentieth year is 732/731 (Finegan, 1998, p. 250, 261).</q></li><br>
<li>JW: Finegan (1998:250) discusses the accession of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoshea">Hoshea</a> in Section 425 and dates it to
between Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 732 BCE and Nisan (Mar./Apr.) 731 BCE.</li><br>
</ul>

<li>This dates Jotham's first year to between Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 751 BCE and Nisan (Mar./Apr.) 750 BCE</li><br>
<li>According to <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233046156_Amos's_Earthquake_An_Extraordinary_Middle_East_Seismic_Event_of_750_BC">Austin et. al. (2000)</a>,
this dates the first year of Jotham's rule to 750 BCE.</li><br>
<li>If one accepts <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>'s
supposition that the incense incident took place during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sukkot">Tabernacle holiday (aka Sukkot)</a>, Jotham's first year would
have been between Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 751 BCE and Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 750 BCE which would date the earthquake to the start of his first year in
Tishri (Sept./Oct.) 751 BCE.</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>


</table>


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Assyrian Inscription (49) of Tiglath-Pileser III (r. 745-727 BCE) in English
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Inscription 49</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/131/mode/2up">
Tadmor and Yamada (2011:131-132)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/131/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
<li>Sarrabanu is mentioned on pages 97, 102, 119, and 136</li>
<li>Hoshea is mentioned in Inscriptions 42 and 49 on pages 106 and 131-132 respectively</li>
</ul>


Rev. 9) [I conquered the land Bit-Humri]a (Israel) in [its] entire[ty (and) I brought] t[o Assyria ..., together with] their [belon]gings.<br><br>

Rev. 10-11) [... (and) I placed Hoshea as] king over them. [They brought ... to the city] Sarrabanu, before me.

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Description of Inscription 49
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Inscription 49</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/127/mode/2up">
Tadmor and Yamada (2011:128)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/127/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
</ul>

49<br><br>

A large fragment of a clay tablet that was reconstructed from three smaller fragments and that was discovered in the
Nabil temple (Ezida) at Kallju preserves fifty-eight lines of a long summary inscription of Tiglath-pileser III. The
beginning of the obverse and the end of the reverse are now missing, and the extant text contains descriptions of the
following events: the defeat of Sarduri (743), the campaign to Urartu in which the Assyrians marched as far as Turugpa
(735) (obv. 1'-5'); the conquest and annexation of Urartu (739, 736-735) — the conquest of Ulluba (obv. 6'-8"), the
enlargement of the provinces of Assur-iqisa (obv. 9'-10'), the chief steward (obv. 11'-13'), the chief cupbearer (
obv. 14'-16'), the land Na'iri (obv. 17'-19'), and the turtanu (obv. 20'-23'); the conquest of Bit-Agusi (743-740)
(obv. 24'-25'); the conquest of Unqi (740, 738) (obv. 26'-27'); the annexation of the north Syrian coast (738)
(rev. 1-2); the conquest of Bit-Haza'ili (733-732) (rev. 3-4); the submission of Tyre (733-732) (rev. 5-8);
the conquest of northern Israel (733-732) and the replacement of its king, Peqah, with Hoshea (731) (rev. 9-11);
the forceful extraction of tribute from a king (of Ashkelon?) (rev. 12); the campaign against Hananu of Gaza
and the submission of Gaza (734) (rev. 13-16); the defeat of Samsi (733) (rev. 17-22); the acknowledgment of
Assyrian sovereignty by an unknown ruler, possibly an Egyptian pharaoh (734 or 733) (rev. 23-25); the receipt
of tribute from Metenna of Tyre (730?) (rev. 26); the receipt of tribute from Hulli of Tabal (730 or 729?)
(rev. 27-29); and the receipt of tribute, probably from some distant Arabian tribes (733-732) (rev. 30-31).
Although the beginning of the inscription is missing, the text must have originally included an account
concerning events in Babylonia and Media since the inscription follows a geographic pattern that is common
to other summary inscriptions. Either text no. 51 or text no. 52 may represent that missing portion.
Tadmor referred to this text as Summary Inscription 9 (Summ. 9) in Tigl. III.

</p>
</div>
</div>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Assyrian Inscription (49) of Tiglath-Pileser III (r. 745-727 BCE) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Inscription 49</li>
<li>see bottom of page 131 starting with <q>Rev. 9) [I conquered the land Bit-Humri]a (Israel)</q></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/131/mode/2up">
Tadmor and Yamada (2011:131-132)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/131/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
<li>Sarrabanu is mentioned on pages 97, 102, 119, and 136</li>
<li>Hoshea is mentioned in Inscriptions 42 and 49 on pages 106 and 131-132 respectively</li>
</ul>


<iframe src="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/131/mode/2up"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Assyrian Inscription (42) of Tiglath-Pileser III (r. 745-727 BCE) in English
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Inscription 42</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/105/mode/2up">
Tadmor and Yamada (2011:106)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/105/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
<li>Sarrabanu is mentioned on pages 97, 102, 119, and 136</li>
<li>Hoshea is mentioned in Inscriptions 42 and 49 on pages 106 and 131-132 respectively</li>
</ul>


17'b-19’a) [I/they] killed Peqah, their king, and I placed Hoshea [as king o]ver them. I received from
them ten talents of gold, ... talents of silver, [together with] their [proper]ty, and [I brou]ght them [to Assyria].<br><br>

19’b-22’a) As for Samsi, queen of the Arabs, at Mount Saqurri, [I] de[feated 9,400 (of her people)]. I took
away (from her) 1,000 people, 30,000 camels, 20,000 oxen, [...] ..., 5,000 (pouches) of all types of aromatics,
.., thrones of her gods, [the military equipment (and) staffs of her goddess(es)], (and) her property.

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Description of Inscription 42
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Inscription 42</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/103/mode/2up">
Tadmor and Yamada (2011:103)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/103/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
</ul>

42<br><br>

This summary inscription is found on a large, fragmentarily preserved stone slab, most likely a colossal pavement slab
like the one inscribed with text no. 39. The object was discovered in the mid-nineteenth century at Kalhu, but left
in situ. It is probably the second slab of a long summary inscription that was written from beginning to end on
three consecutive slabs; the first and third slabs of the series have not survived, save perhaps for a tiny
fragment (text no. 45) containing part of a description of Tiglath-pileser’s Babylonian campaigns. The extant
text contains reports of the following events in the west: the annexation of northern and central Syria (738)
(lines 1’-5’a); the annexation of Damascus (733-732) (lines 5’b-8’a); the campaign against Hantinu of Gaza (734)
(lines 8’b-15’a); the partial annexation of Israel (733-732) (lines 15’b-19’a); the campaign against Samsi (733)
(lines 19’b-27’a); the receipt of tribute from Arab tribes (733-732) (lines 27’b-33’); the appointment of Idibi’ilu
as the “gatekeeper facing Egypt” (734) (lines 34’-35’); and possibly the setting up of a stele (lines 36’-38’).
This text is referred to as Summary Inscription 4 (Summ. 4) in Tadmor, Tigl. III.

</p>
</div>
</div>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Assyrian Inscription (42) of Tiglath-Pileser III (r. 745-727 BCE) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Inscription 42</li>
<li>see bottom 2nd column on right page starting with <q>17'b-19’a) [I/they] killed Peqah, their king</q></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/105/mode/2up">
Tadmor and Yamada (2011:106)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/105/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
<li>Sarrabanu is mentioned on pages 97, 102, 119, and 136</li>
<li>Hoshea is mentioned in Inscriptions 42 and 49 on pages 106 and 131-132 respectively</li>
</ul>


<iframe src="https://archive.org/details/the-royal-inscriptions-of-tiglath-pileser-iii-king-of-assyria-744-727-bc-and-sha/page/105/mode/2up"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Finegan (1998) Sections 425 and 426 dealing with the date of the accession of Hosea
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Sections 425 and 426</li>
<li>from Finegan (1998:249-251)</li>

</ul>

<b>425.</b> In one of his inscriptions Tiglath-pileser III (744-727 B.C.) mentions receiving tribute from a number of kings including
Azariah of Judah.<sup>450</sup> The reference belongs to the third year of the reign of Tiglath-pileser; since he departed from the traditional
system of counting regnal years and included his accession year (745 B.C.) in the numbering, his third year was 743 B.C.<sup>451</sup>
In another text, dated according to the eponym lists in 732 B.C., he speaks
of the defeat of Rezon.<sup>452</sup> This is probably the same event as that mentioned in 2 Kgs 16:9 ("he [Tiglath-pileser] killed Rezin") and
provides a date for the submission of Ahaz of Judah to the Assyrian king (2 Kgs 16:7) as well as for the deportation of Northern
Israelites by Tiglath-pileser III (2 Kgs 15:29) and the change of rule from Pekah to Hoshea (2 Kgs 15:30), the assassination of Pekah
and <b>the accession of Hoshea falling between Tishri (Sept/Oct) 732 and Nisan (Mar/Apr) 731.</b><sup>453</sup><br><br>


<b>426.</b> Since the accession year of Hoshea was 732/731 (§425), his ninth and last year, in which Samaria fell to the Assyrians and the northern kingdom
came to an end (2 Kgs 17:6; 18:10), was 723/722, and the specific date was after Nisan 1, 723, therefore probably in the summer fighting season
of 723.<sup>454</sup> The Assyrian king was Shalmaneser V (2 Kgs 18:9). A Babylonian Chronicle (B. M. 92502) states (1.27-31) as the noteworthy event in the
reign of Shalmaneser V that the city of Shamarain was destroyed, surely a cuneiform record of the fall of the capital of Northern Israel, as per
the biblical account. The Babylonian Chronicle goes on to sav that Shalmaneser (V) died in his fifth year, in the month of Tebetu (Dec/Jan),
and that on the twelfth day of that month (Dec 20, 722) his successor Sargon (II) acceded to the throne of Assyria, with Sargon's first year
beginning in Nisan 721.<sup>455</sup> In some of his own late inscriptions Sargon II claims that at the beginning of his rule, in his first year of reign,
he captured Samaria, carried off 27,290 people from it, and resettled the city.<sup>456</sup> This is probably an appropriation of honor for himself of
what his predecessor had done in a three-year siege (2 Kgs 17:6; 18:10), and may reflect the idea that an Assyrian king must always have
accomplished something militarily significant immediately at the outset of his reign, and it has been shown to be probable that it was only
late in 720 as a part of a western campaign, that Sargon first came to Samaria to deport the people and to rebuild the city as the center of a
new province called Samarina.<sup>457</sup>



<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>
450 Luckenbill, Ancient Records 1:770; ANET 282; ANEA 193.<br><br>

451. Poebel, JNES 2 (1943): 89 n. 23.<br><br>

452 Luckenbill, Ancient Records 1:779; ANET 283; ANEA 194; cf. Thiele, Mysterious Numbers (1951), 90, 106, 121; Albright, BASOR 100 (Dec 1945): 22 n. 26.<br><br>

453 McFall, "Translation Guide," 31, nos. 45, 46; cf. Nadav Na'aman,
"Historical and Chronological Notes on the Kingdoms of Israel and Judah in the 8th Century BC," in VT36 (July 1986): 71-82:
Pekah twenty years from 749 to 731/730 and Hoshea nine years 731/730-723/722.<br><br>

454 Thiele, Chronology, S3, 59; Thiele, Mysterious Numbers (1983), 163; McFall, "Translation Guide," 33 nos. 49, 50.<br><br>

455 ANET 301-303; Thiele, Mysterious Numbers (1983), 163-164.<br><br>

456 Luckenbill, Ancient Records 2: 4, 55; ANET 284-285.<br><br>

457 Thiele, Mysterious Numbers (1983), 163-168, citing Hayim Tadmor, "Campaigns of Sargon II," 38.<br><br>



</p>
</div>
</div>



</p>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Notes - Calendars and Chronology
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<div class="tooltipfullfoto"><img src="http://www.deadseaquake.info/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/Table9_34_Onstott2015.png"
alt="Table 9.34 from Onstott (2015)" width="100%">
<span class="tooltiptextfullfoto" >from Onstott (2015)</span>
</div><br><br>


<a href="https://www.academia.edu/s/41bc1b5afd">Onstott (2015:393-395)</a> notes the following:

<blockquote>
The conclusion of regnal reckoning is as follows: the chronology of the Judges Era through the end of David's reign followed the
linear, postdating system in which reign lengths were simply added together (a method currently popular in biblical scholarship).
During this time, Israel's records and archives were handled by the priesthood (1 Chr 9:22; 18:16; 2 Sam 20:25).
Under Solomon's administration, the linear-priestly system of reckoning chronology was abandoned in favor of the
more sophisticated Egyptian antedating system, which depicted reigns more accurately. Solomon's strong ties
with Egypt probably influenced this shift (1 Kings 9; see Table 9.31). This transfer probably occurred with the origin
of the new document called "The Acts of Solomon" (1 Kgs 11:41), which was later inserted into the The Book of the Kings
of Israel and Judah (2 Chr 16:11; see chap. 8.V.).<br><br>

...<br><br>

These conclusions are supported by another fact. Uzziah (Azariah), king of Judah, enjoyed one of the longest and most
stable reigns in the Southern Kingdom's history. The date that Scripture provides for Uzziah allows no other conclusion
for Jeroboam II's reign but the use of the linear-priestly postdating (accession-year) method. From all indications,
this method continued to be employed in the Northern Kingdom until the kingdom's annihilation under Sargon and
Shalmaneser V.<sup>172</sup> Both of these systems are clarified by the scribe's synchronization of the regnal years of
Judah's kings with the regnal dates of the kings of Israel (see Table 9.34).

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


172. MB, 318, emphasis added. See also, Hornung, Ancient Egyptian Chronology, 13.<br><br>



</p>
</div>
</div>

</blockquote>

Emmanuel Academic Publishing, Incorporated. Excerpts on Micro and Macro Chronology</a><br><br>


<a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_in_the/5TZXAQAAQBAJ?hl=en">
Schoors, Antoon. The Kingdoms of Israel and Judah in the Eighth and Seventh Centuries B.C.E.. 
United States, SBL Press, 2013.</a><br><br>

<h7>Background and Biography</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Background and Biography</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Amos.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Amos"></iframe>

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 1:1-2 - English (NIV)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos%201&version=NIV">Bible Gateway (NIV translation)</a></li>
</ul>

1 The words of Amos, one of the shepherds of <a href="https://bibleatlas.org/tekoa.htm">Tekoa</a>
— the vision he saw concerning Israel <b>two years before the earthquake</b>,
when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah">Judah</a> and
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam</a> son of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jehoash_of_Israel">Jehoash</a>
<abbr Title="Hebrew Joash, a variant of Jehoash">[a]</abbr> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)">Israel</a>.<br><br>

2 He said:<br>

<blockquote>
“The Lord roars from Zion<br>
and thunders from Jerusalem;<br>
the pastures of the shepherds dry up,<br>
and the top of Carmel withers.”<br>
</blockquote>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 1:1-2 - Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.chabad.org/library/bible_cdo/aid/16173/jewish/Chapter-1.htm">chabad.org</a></li>
</ul>


<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

א<br><br>

דִּבְרֵ֣י עָמ֔וֹס אֲשֶׁר־הָיָ֥ה בַנֹּֽקְדִ֖ים מִתְּק֑וֹעַ אֲשֶׁר֩ חָזָ֨ה עַל־יִשְׂרָאֵ֜ל בִּימֵ֣י | עֻזִּיָּ֣ה מֶֽלֶךְ־יְהוּדָ֗ה וּבִימֵ֞י יָֽרָבְעָ֚ם בֶּן־יוֹאָשׁ֙ מֶ֣לֶךְ יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל שְׁנָתַ֖יִם לִפְנֵ֥י הָרָֽעַשׁ:

</font>
</blockquote>

<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

ב<br><br>

וַיֹּאמַ֓ר | יְהֹוָה֙ מִצִּיּ֣וֹן יִשְׁאָ֔ג וּמִירֽוּשָׁלִַ֖ם יִתֵּ֣ן קוֹל֑וֹ וְאָֽבְלוּ֙ נְא֣וֹת הָֽרֹעִ֔ים וְיָבֵ֖שׁ רֹ֥אשׁ הַכַּרְמֶֽל:

</font>
</blockquote>


</p>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Other possible earthquake and tsunami references in Amos</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 9:1
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 9:1 - English (NIV)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+9&version=NIV">Bible Gateway (NIV translation)</a></li>
</ul>

<b>Israel to Be Destroyed</b><br><br>

9 I saw the Lord standing by the altar, and he said:<br><br>

<blockquote>
“<b>Strike the tops of the pillars<br>
so that the thresholds shake</b>.<br>
Bring them down on the heads of all the people;<br>
those who are left I will kill with the sword.<br>
Not one will get away,<br>
none will escape.
</blockquote>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 9:1 - Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.chabad.org/library/bible_cdo/aid/16181/jewish/Chapter-9.htm">chabad.org</a></li>
</ul>


<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

א<br><br>

רָאִ֨יתִי אֶת־אֲדֹנָ֜י נִצָּ֣ב עַל־הַמִּזְבֵּ֗חַ וַיֹּאמֶר֩ הַ֨ךְ הַכַּפְתּ֜וֹר וְיִרְעֲשׁ֣וּ הַסִּפִּ֗ים וּבְצָ֙עַם֙ בְּרֹ֣אשׁ כֻּלָּ֔ם וְאַֽחֲרִיתָ֖ם בַּחֶ֣רֶב אֶֽהֱרֹ֑ג לֹֽא־יָנ֚וּס לָהֶם֙ נָ֔ס וְלֹֽא־יִמָּלֵ֥ט לָהֶ֖ם פָּלִֽיט:

</font>
</blockquote>



</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 8:8
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 8:8 - English (NIV)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos%208&version=NIV">Bible Gateway (NIV translation)</a></li>
</ul>

<b>A Basket of Ripe Fruit</b><br><br>

...<br><br>

<blockquote>
8 “<b>Will not the land tremble for this</b>,
and all who live in it mourn?
The whole land will rise like the Nile;
it will be stirred up and then sink
like the river of Egypt.
</blockquote>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 8:8 - Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">

<font size="+2">

ח<br><br>

הַ֚עַל זֹאת֙ לֹֽא־תִרְגַּ֣ז הָאָ֔רֶץ וְאָבַ֖ל כָּל־יוֹשֵׁ֣ב בָּ֑הּ וְעָֽלְתָ֚ה כָאֹר֙ כֻּלָּ֔הּ וְנִגְרְשָׁ֥ה וְנִשְׁקְעָ֖ה (כתיב וְנִשְׁקְהָ֖) כִּיא֥וֹר מִצְרָֽיִם

</font>
</blockquote>

<b>Israel to Be Destroyed</b><br><br>

...<br><br>

<blockquote>
5 “The Lord, the Lord Almighty—<br>
<b>he touches the earth and it melts</b>,<br>
and all who live in it mourn;<br>
<b>the whole land rises like the Nile,<br>
then sinks like the river of Egypt</b>;<br>
</blockquote>


</p>

<font size="+2">

ה<br><br>

וַאדֹנָ֨י יֱהֹוִ֜ה הַצְּבָא֗וֹת הַנּוֹגֵ֚עַ בָּאָ֙רֶץ֙ וַתָּמ֔וֹג וְאָֽבְל֖וּ כָּל־י֣וֹשְׁבֵי בָ֑הּ וְעָֽלְתָ֚ה כַיְאֹר֙ כֻּלָּ֔הּ וְשָֽׁקְעָ֖ה כִּיאֹ֥ר מִצְרָֽיִם

</font>

Amos 5:8 - tsunami ?
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 5:8 - English (NIV)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+5&version=NIV">Bible Gateway (NIV translation)</a></li>
</ul>

<b>A Lament and Call to Repentance</b><br><br>

...<br><br>

<blockquote>
8 He who made the Pleiades and Orion,<br>
who turns midnight into dawn<br>
and darkens day into night,<br>
<b>who calls for the waters of the sea<br>
and pours them out over the face of the land</b>—<br>
the Lord is his name.<br>
</blockquote>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 5:8 - Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>

<font size="+2">

ח<br><br>

עֹשֵׂ֨ה כִימָ֜ה וּכְסִ֗יל וְהֹפֵ֚ךְ לַבֹּ֙קֶר֙ צַלְמָ֔וֶת וְי֖וֹם לַ֣יְלָה הֶחְשִׁ֑יךְ הַקּוֹרֵ֣א לְמֵֽי־הַיָּ֗ם וַֽיִּשְׁפְּכֵ֛ם עַל־פְּנֵ֥י הָאָ֖רֶץ יְהֹוָ֥ה שְׁמֽוֹ

</font>
</blockquote>
