<div class="top expand">
Amos 9:6 - tsunami ?
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 9:6 - English (NIV)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos%209&version=NIV">Bible Gateway (NIV translation)</a></li>
</ul>

<b>Israel to Be Destroyed</b><br><br>

...<br><br>

<blockquote>
6 he builds his lofty palace<abbr Title="The meaning of the Hebrew for this phrase is uncertain.">[a]</abbr> in the heavens<br>
and sets its foundation<abbr Title="The meaning of the Hebrew for this phrase is uncertain.">[b]</abbr> on the earth;<br>
<b>he calls for the waters of the sea<br>
and pours them out over the face of the land</b>—<br>
the Lord is his name.
</blockquote>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Amos 9:6 - Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.chabad.org/library/bible_cdo/aid/16181/jewish/Chapter-9.htm">chabad.org</a></li>
</ul>


<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

ו<br><br>

הַבּוֹנֶ֚ה בַשָּׁמַ֙יִם֙ מַֽעֲלוֹתָ֔יו (כתיב מַֽעֲלוֹתָ֔ו) וַֽאֲגֻדָּת֖וֹ עַל־אֶ֣רֶץ יְסָדָ֑הּ הַקֹּרֵ֣א לְמֵי־הַיָּ֗ם וַיִּשְׁפְּכֵ֛ם עַל־פְּנֵ֥י הָאָ֖רֶץ יְהֹוָ֥ה שְׁמֽוֹ:

</font>
</blockquote>



</p>

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">


<tr>
<th>Year</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>766/765 - 751 BCE<br>(Thiele's chronology)</td>
<td><q>two years before the earthquake,
when <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah">Judah</a> and
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam (II)</a> son of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jehoash_of_Israel">Jehoash</a>
<abbr Title="Hebrew Joash, a variant of Jehoash">[a]</abbr> was king of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)">Israel</a></q>.</td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a>
<ul>
<li>William F. Albright dates Uzziah's reign to 783–742 BC.(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
<li>Edwin R. Thiele's chronology has Uzziah becoming coregent with
his father Amaziah in 792/791 BCE and sole ruler of Judah after
his father's death in 768/767 BCE. Uzziah was struck with leprosy
for disobeying God (2 Kings 15:5, 2 Chronicles 26:19–21).
Thiele dates Uzziah's being struck with leprosy to 751/750 BCE,
at which time his son Jotham took over the government, with Uzziah
living on until 740/739 BCE. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pekah">Pekah</a> became king of Israel in
the last year of Uzziah's reign. (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeroboam_II">Jeroboam (II)</a>
<ul>
<li>William F. Albright has dated his reign to 786–746 BC (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
<li>E. R. Thiele says he was coregent with Jehoash 793 to 782 BC and sole ruler 782 to 753 BC.
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>If we use Theile's chronology, Jeroboam II and Uzziah were both ruling (as sole rulers) between the
years of 768/767 and 753 BCE. Since the earthquake was two years after a time when both men were ruling, this
leads to a time bracket of 766/765 - 751 BCE.</li>
<li>References
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/1355182">
Albright, W. F. (1945). "The Chronology of the Divided Monarchy of Israel."
Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research 100: 16-22.</a></li>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/mysteriousnumber0000thie">
Thiele, E. R. (1983). The Mysterious Numbers of the Hebrew Kings, Academic Books.</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>


</table>


<h7>Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li>none listed</li>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Roaring of a Lion and Earthquake Imagery - Roberts (2012)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://escholarship.org/uc/item/9rv3v8tc">Roberts (2012:194-200)</a></li>
</ul>


CHAPTER FIVE:THE CONTEXT OF AMOS’S EARTHQUAKE IMAGERY<br><br>

...<br><br>


2. Roaring of a Lion and Earthquake Imagery<br><br>

Leonine imagery is found throughout the Hebrew Bible, often used in
metaphorical descriptions of YHWH’s power. Amos 1:2a [] “YHWH roars from Zion and
he gives his voice from Jerusalem” is one such text that provides a metaphorical description of YHWH.
The verse concludes, “the pastures of the shepherds mourn, and the top of Carmel withers” suggesting judgment
is behind YHWH’s roaring though the type of judgment and reason for judgment are unclear. This verse, then,
has stirred considerable debate about the meaning of YHWH “roaring like a lion.” Most scholars have focused on a
thunderstorm couched in theophany imagery because of the formulaic language [], literally, “he gives voice,”
which is found in texts such as Exod 9:23; 1 Sam 12:17–18, Psa 18:7–15 (Heb. 18:8–16)/2 Sam 22:14, Psa 46:7,
and Psa 68:34 arguing that the formulaic language employed by Amos is part of a long tradition of storm-god imagery.<sup>1</sup>
While some of these texts make clear connections between roaring and a thunderstorm, Amos 1:2 does not make this explicit link.
The imagery of YHWH roaring, however, in Amos 1:2 is better understood as referring to an earthquake due to parallel
imagery in a Neo-Assyrian earthquake omen, a later allusion to this verse in Joel 3:16 (Eng. 4:16), and evidence from
earthquake survivors’ descriptions of earthquakes.<br><br>

Connecting “roaring like a lion” in Amos 1:2a with
an earthquake has had a long but uneven history of supporters. Two early proponents of this view come from early
Jewish interpreters; Eliezer of Beaugency, a Medieval Jewish commentator and grandson of Rashi first advocated
this position in the thirteenth century and Zvi Hirsch Chajes, a Talmudic scholar from the nineteenth century also
understood “roar” in this manner.<sup>2</sup> Interestingly, Chajes argued
elsewhere that the roar was from a thunderstorm not from an earthquake perhaps foreshadowing twentieth century debate
on this text. The unevenness expressed by Chajes is also found in Artur Weiser’s 1929 work, where he first suggested a
catastrophic earthquake.<sup>3</sup> Weiser, however, in his later commentary on the twelve Minor Prophets wrote about
“the sound of thunder.”<sup>4</sup> The strongest advocate of connecting an earthquake with the imagery of Amos 1:2 is
Julius Morgenstern, as part of his four part extensive study on Amos published in Hebrew Union
College Annual. In Morgenstern’s words, “Furthermore, whatever Yahweh’s roaring, as implied in the verb [],
may have originally connoted, thunder perhaps, or even the roaring of the lion, in this passage, as the
continuation of the v. indicates, it depicts the deep, roaring, rumbling noise of the earthquake.”<sup>5</sup><br><br>

Outside of these proponents, over the last decades few scholars have argued for an earthquake, as they have focused
on a narrow demarcation of storm-god imagery tied to thunder. For example, in Brent Strawn’s work, What is Stronger
than a Lion?, he notes that Amos 1:2 has connections to the “theophanic tradition of the thunderstorm” constraining
“roaring” to thunder rather than broader notions of celestial or terrestrial phenomena.<sup>6</sup> Part of the reason behind
the shift to a theophanic thunderstorm is due to scholarships’ shift associating nature’s trembling solely with thunder
rather than seeing earthquakes as equal or more plausible imagery. In fact, in Frank Moore Cross’s seminal work,
Canaanite Myth and Hebrew Epic, he notes that the “explicit language of the storm has been largely eschewed”
and uses Amos 1:2 as an example.<sup>7</sup> In addition to Frank Moore Cross, the work of Samuel Loewenstamm is instructive
as he demonstrates there is a long history of nature trembling in Akkadian and Canaanite literature.<sup>8</sup> Loewenstamm
did not slavishly link nature’s trembling to thunder but saw it as a much larger phenomena. This motif led
Loewenstamm to conclude that the model of nature-shaking
theophany came to Israel under Canaanite influence, which borrowed it from Akkadian literature.
These distinctions are more than banal discussion in terminology and will be clearer when examining neo-Assyrian
evidence that relates to Amos 1:2.<br><br>

Outside of these interpreters, it is important to draw attention to Moshe Weiss, who in a number of studies,
has focused his attention on the use of the metaphor in Amos 1:2.<sup>9</sup> Weiss divides interpretive opinion into
two categories: the tenor is a natural acoustic phenomenon, such as thunder, an earthquake, an east wind,
or all three together, or the tenor is a theophany.<sup>10</sup> Weiss provides an extensive survey of scholarly views
through most of the twentieth century before arriving at his interpretive decision. In Weiss’s view, “roaring”
awakens the “complex of associations aroused in the hearer’s mind by the roar of the lion.”<sup>11</sup> In sum, Weiss
argues that the tenor of verse 2a is that it refers to the appearance of God where his action is active, but
the action of the existence is passive, thus the Lord is not seen, he is only heard. Weiss’s survey of scholarship
is instructive, but it highlights that scholarship has favored demarcating theophany image into thunder rather than
seeing theophany language more broadly as all types of weather phenomena.<br><br>

A Neo-Assyrian earthquake oracle from the seventh century provides new light to read Amos 1:2 in light of an earthquake.
Experts in divination, especially celestial divination, compiled lists and studied observable celestial phenomena,
which were seen as divine communication. In the words of Francesca Rochberg, “Every phenomenon in heaven or on earth,
every experience, every symptom of a disease, every birth and human physical attribute, were
potential conveyors of divine messages, and so forecasts or correlations to social, political, or economic events
were obtainable from all these phenomena.”<sup>12</sup> The origins of Mesopotamian scholarly and literary divination
come from the Old Babylonian Period and reach their zenith in the seventh-century library of Assurbanipal at Nineveh.<sup>13</sup><br><br>

An overwhelming majority of tablets found at Nineveh were written during the reigns of Esarhaddon (679 BCE to 668 BCE) and
Assurbanipal (667 to 626 BCE). Even more specific, most tablets were written between 670 to 665 BCE due to dating scribal
colophons at the end of the tablet. As mentioned above, the origins of this divination can be traced to the Old Babylonian
Period and earthquake omen texts are first known from Nuzi, best known in biblical scholarship for parallels drawn
between Nuzi tablets and the patriarchal period.<sup>14</sup><br><br>

The oracle studied here, however, does not have any parallels to other omen texts but was composed by a well-known Neo-Assyrian scribe,
Issar-s¥umu-eres, who wrote thirty-eight other omens found at Nineveh. The omen concerns what to do if an earthquake strikes during
sabatu, the eleventh month of the Assyrian calendar. Overall, the omen is in good condition with most damage occurring at the right
side of the tablet. The tablet is thirty lines in total, fifteen lines each on the obverse and reverse, with the relevant portion
consisting of lines eight through ten on the obverse. The excerpted portion reads:<br><br>

8. 1 AN-u is-su-ma KI.TIM ir-[tu-ub] &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
If the sky shouts and the earth qu[akes]:<br><br>

9. me-res KUR i-ma-at-ti su du bu? uk? x[xxx] &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
the cultivated fields will diminish...[]...<br><br>

10. 1<sup>d</sup> e-ri-is-ki-gal ik-kil-la-sa GIM UR.[MAHSUB-d]i &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

If Ereskigal [utter]s her roar like a li[on]:<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
the earth will throw the land into ruins.<sup>15</sup><br><br>


As mentioned above, the omen focuses on what to do if there is an earthquake during the eleventh month.
The word “earthquake” is found in lines one, six, eight, twelve, fourteen, and on the reverse in lines
one and eleven. Beyond this phrase, the refrain “if the sky shouts” is found five times in the omen.
The omen does not provide a subject for the sky “shouting” but other omens in this same corpus refer to
Adad, the storm-god, shouting and thundering.<sup>16</sup> In these omens, however, the earth never shakes so it
remains unclear if shouting and/or thundering causes an earthquake. At the same time, the structure of
the omens is formulated in conditionals: if a occurs, then b will occur, a common Near Eastern form of a
protasis and apodosis. Grammatically, scholarship has seen the relationship not as a causal but a
correlation; thus, if a, expect b.<sup>17</sup> With this background in mind, the omen is best read, if Ereskigal
roars like a lion, then expect the earth will turn the land into ruins. It is important to note that the
wording of the apodosis appears cumbersome. It is not “expect the land to turn into ruins” but
“expect that the earth will turn the land into ruins.”<sup>18</sup> The terrestrial focus of this line is made even clearer when
Ereskigal’s religious history is understood: Ereskigal, translated as “Queen of the Great Below” was the goddess of the underworld.<sup>19</sup>
Thus, Ereskigal’s roaring from the underworld caused the earth to turn the land into ruins. In other words, it is the roaring
that causes the earthquake.<br><br>

The imagery in this omen until this point has not been connected with Amos 1:2 but suggests a number of
intriguing parallels. As Samuel Loewenstamm has argued, it is clear that storm-god imagery has a long
history in Akkadian and Canaanite literature. This is not to say that Amos 1:2 borrowed from a
Neo-Assyrian omen but to suggest that a contextual reading of a lion roaring outside the Hebrew
Bible and close in date to Amos is understood as an earthquake. In addition, as noted above,
theophany imagery should not be narrowly confined to just thunderstorms. In the Neo-Assyrian omen,
the sky shouting is found alongside the earth quaking raising the likelihood that the ancients had a
broader understanding of terrestrial phenomena.

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


1 For a list of scholars who have advocated this position, see Karl Möller, A Prophet in Debate:
The Rhetoric of Persuasion in the Book of Amos (JSOTSup 372; Sheffield: Sheffield Academic Press, 2003),
160, fn. 22–23.<br><br>

2 Meir Weiss, The Bible From Within: The Method of Total Interpretation (Jerusalem: Magnes Press, 1984), 196–197.<br><br>

3 Artur Weiser, Die Profetie des Amos (BZAW 53; Giessen: Töpelmann, 1929), 84.<br><br>

4 Artur Weiser, Das Buch der zwölf kleinen Propheten (Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 1956).<br><br>

5 Julius Morgenstern, “Amos Studies I,” HUCA 11 (1936): 19–140, esp. 137 n. 144. Morgenstern will
further link Amos 1:2 with the Day of Yahweh, noting, “In this respect the picture here agrees
completely with that of the Day of Yahweh in Zech. 14, with its earthquake likened to the terrible
earthquake in the days of Uzziah. Here the picture goes even beyond, and far beyond, that of Zech. 14;
here the earthquake will even affect both heaven and earth. It is indeed the utmost extreme in the
depicting of an earthquake.”<br><br>

6 Brent Strawn, What is Stronger than a Lion? Leonine Image and Metaphor in the Hebrew Bible and the
Ancient Near East, (OBO 212; Göttingen: Vandenhocke and Ruprecht, 2005), 59–62; 265–266.<br><br>

7 Frank Moore Cross, Canaanite Myth and Hebrew Epic (Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1972), 156–177.<br><br>

8 Samuel E. Loewenstamm, “The Trembling of Nature during the Theophany,” in Comparative Studies in Biblical and
Ancient Oriental Literatures (AOAT 204; Kevelaer: Bercker & Butzon; Neukirchen-Vluyn: Neukirchener, 1984), 173–89.<br><br>

9 Meir Weiss, “On the Traces of a Biblical Metaphor,” Tarbiz 34 (1964–1965): 107–28, 211–23, 303–18 (Heb); idem,
“Methodologisches über die Behandlung der Metapher dargelegt an Am. 1,2” TZ 23 (1967): 1–25; idem, The Bible from Within, 196–207.<br><br>

10 Weiss, The Bible from Within, 196–197.<br><br>

11 Weiss, The Bible from Within, 206.<br><br>

12 Francesca Rochberg, The Heavenly Writing: Divination, Horoscopy, and Astronomy
in Mesopotamian Culture(Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2004), 47.<br><br>

13 Rochberg, The Heavenly Writing, 63–65. Omens continued to be transmitted into the Persian and
Seleucid periods, but the building of Assurbanipal’s library enabled the bulk of exemplars to be found there.<br><br>

14 The Nuzi omens were first published by E. R. Lacheman, “An Omen Text from Nuzi,” RA 34 (1937): 1–8.
See also, the discussion in Hermann Hunger and David Pingree, Astral Sciences in Mesopotamia (Leiden: Brill, 1999), 11.<br><br>

15 Hermann Hunger, Astrological Reports to Assyrian Kings (SAA 8; Helsinki: Helsinki University Press, 1992), 19–20, omen 36.
Another Assyrian parallel is often deduced for Amos 1:2. The Middle Assyrian, “Fable of the Fox” describes the dog’s strength as:
“My strength is overpowering, I am the claw of theZu®-bird, a very lion... At my terrible bellow the mountains and the rivers
dry up[e-ta-na-ab-ba-la-a].” See W. G. Lambert, Babylonian Wisdom Literature (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1960), 192–193.<br><br>

16 Hunger, Astrological Reports, “shouting” in omens 1, 31, 32; Hunger, Astrological Reports, “thundering” in omens 1, 31, 32, 33.
Omen 36 later states, “either Adad will thun[der], or a storm will come, or [...], or there will bean earth[quake].” <br><br>

17 See the explanation in Rochberg, The Heavenly Writing, 58.<br><br>

18 The addition of this subject in the apodosis, not only supplies a grammatical subject, but also suggests that at
least in a rudimentary way, the Assyrians saw the ground as the reason behind the earthquake. Lest this statement
sound elementary, the modern theory of plate tectonics was only suggested in the 1950’s.<br><br>

19 Ereskigal, known in Akkadian as Allatu,has a long religious history. She appears in “Inanna’s Descent to the Underworld”
when Inanna is led by Neti through the seven gates of the netherworld to enter the underworld where, upon crouching
and stripping bare in front of Ereskigal, Inanna tries to dethrone her sister. Enki will trick Ereskigal by sending two
mourning specialists to free Inanna from the netherworld. A later myth, “Nergal and Eres¥kigal” is found in part in an
Amarna tablet as well as in the first half of the first millennium. Here, Nergal almost kills Ereskigal before finding
love with Nergal, who previously went to the underworld to cut off her head. See, Thorkild Jacobsen, The Treasures of Darkness:
A History of Mesopotamian Religion (New Haven, London, 1976), 56–59, 229–230; Jeremy Black and Anthony Green, Gods,
Demons and Symbols of Ancient Mesopotamia (Austin: University of Texas, 2006), 77.

<h7>Background and Biography</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Background and Biography</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Zechariah.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Zechariah"></iframe>

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English of Zechariah 14:2-5 (NIV)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Zechariah+14&version=NIV">Bible Gateway (NIV translation)</a></li>
</ul>

2 I will gather all the nations to Jerusalem to fight against it; the city will be captured,
the houses ransacked, and the women raped. Half of the city will go into exile, but the rest
of the people will not be taken from the city. 3 Then the Lord will go out and fight against
those nations, as he fights on a day of battle. 4 On that day his feet will stand on the Mount
of Olives, east of Jerusalem, and the Mount of Olives will be split in two from east to west,
forming a great valley, with half of the mountain moving north and half moving south. 5 You will
flee by my mountain valley, for it will extend to <abbr Title="Location unknown - presumably near Jerusalem">Azel</abbr>.
<b>You will flee as you fled from the earthquake
<abbr Title="Or 5 My mountain valley will be blocked and will extend to Azel. It will be blocked as it was blocked because of the earthquake">[a]</abbr>
in the days of Uzziah king of Judah</b>.
Then the Lord my God will come, and all the holy ones with him.


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Hebrew of Zechariah 14:2-5
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.chabad.org/library/bible_cdo/aid/16218">chabad.org</a></li>
</ul>


<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

ב<br><br>

וְאָֽסַפְתִּ֨י אֶת־כָּל־הַגּוֹיִ֥ם | אֶֽל־יְרֽוּשָׁלִַם֘ לַמִּלְחָמָה֒ וְנִלְכְּדָ֣ה הָעִ֗יר וְנָשַׁ֙סּוּ֙ הַבָּ֣תִּ֔ים וְהַנָּשִׁ֖ים תִּשָּׁכַ֑בְנָה (כתיב תִּשָּׁגַ֑לְנָה) וְיָצָ֞א חֲצִ֚י הָעִיר֙ בַּגּוֹלָ֔ה וְיֶ֣תֶר הָעָ֔ם לֹ֥א יִכָּרֵ֖ת מִן־הָעִֽיר:

</font>
</blockquote>

<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

ג<br><br>

וְיָצָ֣א יְהֹוָ֔ה וְנִלְחַ֖ם בַּגּוֹיִ֣ם הָהֵ֑ם כְּי֥וֹם הִלָּֽחֲמ֖וֹ בְּי֥וֹם קְרָֽב:

</font>
</blockquote>

<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

ד<br><br>

וְעָֽמְד֣וּ רַגְלָ֣יו בַּיּֽוֹם־הַ֠הוּא עַל־הַ֨ר הַזֵּיתִ֜ים אֲשֶׁ֨ר עַל־פְּנֵ֥י יְרֽוּשָׁלִַם֘ מִקֶּדֶם֒ וְנִבְקַע֩ הַ֨ר הַזֵּיתִ֚ים מֵֽחֶצְיוֹ֙ מִזְרָ֣חָה וָיָ֔מָּה גֵּ֖יא גְּדוֹלָ֣ה מְאֹ֑ד וּמָ֨שׁ חֲצִ֥י הָהָ֛ר צָפ֖וֹנָה וְחֶצְיוֹ־נֶֽגְבָּה:

</font>
</blockquote>
<blockquote dir="ltr" lang="he" >
<font size="+2">

ה<br><br>

וְנַסְתֶּ֣ם גֵּֽיא־הָרַ֗י כִּֽי־יַגִּ֣יעַ גֵּֽי־הָרִים֘ אֶל־אָצַל֒ וְנַסְתֶּ֗ם כַּֽאֲשֶׁ֚ר נַסְתֶּם֙ מִפְּנֵ֣י הָרַ֔עַשׁ בִּימֵ֖י עֻזִּיָּ֣ה מֶֽלֶךְ־יְהוּדָ֑ה וּבָא֙ יְהֹוָ֣ה אֱלֹהַ֔י כָּל־קְדֹשִׁ֖ים עִמָּֽךְ:

</font>
</blockquote>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Embedded
</div>

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">


<tr>
<th>Year</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>768/767 - 751/750 BCE<br>(Thiele's chronology)</td>
<td><q>You will
flee by my mountain valley, for it will extend to <abbr Title="Location unknown - presumably near Jerusalem">Azel</abbr>.
You will flee as you fled from the earthquake
<abbr Title="Or 5 My mountain valley will be blocked and will extend to Azel. It will be blocked as it was blocked because of the earthquake">[a]</abbr>
in the days of Uzziah king of Judah</q></td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a>
<ul>
<li>William F. Albright dates Uzziah's reign to 783–742 BC.(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
<li>Edwin R. Thiele's chronology has Uzziah becoming coregent with
his father Amaziah in 792/791 BCE and sole ruler of Judah after
his father's death in 768/767 BCE. Uzziah was struck with leprosy
for disobeying God (2 Kings 15:5, 2 Chronicles 26:19–21).
Thiele dates Uzziah's being struck with leprosy to 751/750 BCE,
at which time his son Jotham took over the government, with Uzziah
living on until 740/739 BCE. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pekah">Pekah</a> became king of Israel in
the last year of Uzziah's reign. (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>If we use Theile's chronology, Uzziah ruled (as a sole ruler) between the
years of 768/767 and 751/750 BCE.</li>
<li>References
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/1355182">
Albright, W. F. (1945). "The Chronology of the Divided Monarchy of Israel."
Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research 100: 16-22.</a></li>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/mysteriousnumber0000thie">
Thiele, E. R. (1983). The Mysterious Numbers of the Hebrew Kings, Academic Books.</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>


</table>


<h7>Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li>none explicitly specified</li>
<li>splitting of the Mount of Olives in Zechariah 14:4 could echo a seismic effect (e.g.a memory of landslides) from the earlier Quake mentioned in Amos - <br>
<q>4 On that day his feet will stand on the Mount
of Olives, east of Jerusalem, and the Mount of Olives will be split in two from east to west,
forming a great valley, with half of the mountain moving north and half moving south. 5 You will
flee by my mountain valley, for it will extend to <abbr Title="Location unknown - presumably near Jerusalem">Azel</abbr>.
You will flee as you fled from the earthquake
<abbr Title="Or 5 My mountain valley will be blocked and will extend to Azel. It will be blocked as it was blocked because of the earthquake">[a]</abbr>
in the days of Uzziah king of Judah.
Then the Lord my God will come, and all the holy ones with him.</q></li>
</ul>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Location of Azel (aka Azal)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/Ambraseys2009.html">Ambraseys (2009)</a> notes

<blockQuote>
The location of Azal is not certain, but the name may denote some place near the western extremity of the valley
near Jerusalem or a hamlet on the outskirts of Jerusalem.
</blockquote>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Locations</h7>

<ul>
<li>Jerusalem (suggested from the context of the passage)</li>
</ul>

Schoors, Antoon. The Kingdoms of Israel and Judah in the Eighth and Seventh Centuries B.C.E.. 
United States, SBL Press, 2013.</a><br><br>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/IsaiahTargum.html"

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<ul>
<li>Targum Isaiah 28:21 explains or interprets a cryptic passage in Isaiah 28:21 by making reference to one of the Amos Quakes</li>
</ul>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah 28:21 - English (NIV)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah%2028&version=NIV">biblegateway.com (NIV)</a></li>
</ul>



21 The Lord will rise up as he did at Mount Perazim,<br>
he will rouse himself as in the Valley of Gibeon—<br>
to do his work, his strange work,<br>
and perform his task, his alien task.<br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Targum Isaiah 28:21 - English
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">Austin et al (2000:663)</a>,
citing <a href="https://books.google.com/books?id=gjEHAAAACAAJ">Chilton (1987:56)</a>, states that this sentence in Targum Isaiah explains or interprets the verse of Isaiah 28:21</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/targumofisaiah0000unse/page/90/mode/2up">Stenning (1953:90-91)</a></li>
</ul>


21 <b>For as the mountains shook when the glory of the Lord was revealed in the days of Uzziah the King</b>, and like wonders (or, miracles) which he did for
Joshua in the plain of Gibeon, that he might be avenged on the wicked who had transgressed against his Memra, so shall he be revealed that he may be avenged on
them that work strange works as their works, and on them that serve the service of idols as their service.

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah Chapter 28 - English (NIV) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah%2028&version=NIV">biblegateway.com (NIV)</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah%2028&version=NIV#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah Chapter 28 - English and Hebrew (sefaria - Masoretic text) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.28.21?lang=bi">sefaria</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.28.21?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Targum Isaiah Chapter 28 - English and Aramaic - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>See 5th sentence down on Page 90 starting with "21 For as the mountains shook"</li>
<li>can be borrowed with a free account from archive.org</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/targumofisaiah0000unse/page/90/mode/2up">Stenning (1953:90-91)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/targumofisaiah0000unse/page/90/mode/2up">Archive.org</a></li>
</ul>


<iframe src="https://archive.org/details/targumofisaiah0000unse/page/90/mode/2up#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.9.8?lang=bi">Isaiah 9:8</a> appears to describe damage to buildings and fallen trees in Samaria which was due to the Amos Quake</li>
</ul>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah Chapter 9 in English
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.9.8?lang=bi">sefaria</a></li>
</ul>

7 My Lord<br>
<abbr Title="Septuagint reads Let loose pestilence; cf. Amos 4.10. In vv. 7–20 Isaiah alludes to and builds upon Amos 4.10–12.">Let loose a word against Jacob</abbr><br>
And it fell upon Israel<br><br>

8 But all the people <abbr Title="1QIsa reads shouted.">noted</abbr><br>
Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria<br>
In arrogance and haughtiness:<br><br>

9 “Bricks have fallen<br>
We’ll rebuild with dressed stone;<br>
Sycamores have been felled<br>
We’ll grow cedars instead!”<br><br>




</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah Chapter 9 - English and Hebrew (sefaria - Masoretic text) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.9.8?lang=bi">sefaria</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.9.8?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<ul>
<li>Other passages in Isaiah which describe shaking may be influenced by the Amos Quake</li>
</ul>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Other passages in Isaiah with shaking - Embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaiah">Isaiah</a> appears to have written his prophetic book between 740 and 686 BCE</li>
<li>Seismic shaking is alluded to in multiple locations usually describing a future time.</li>
<li>The shaking may have been familiar to his contemporaries due to the relatively recent Amos Quakes</li>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/scriptureotherar0000unse/page/196/mode/2up">
Freedman and Welch (1994:196)</a> suggest that <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.5.25?lang=bi">Isaiah 5:25</a> <q>appears to be a direct reference
to the quake in Uzziah's day.</q></li>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/scriptureotherar0000unse/page/196/mode/2up">
Freedman and Welch (1994:196)</a> suggest that <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.6.4?lang=bi">Isaiah 6:4</a>
<q>may reflect <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.9.1?lang=bi">Amos 9:1</a></q></li>
</ul>




<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah Chapter 2 - English and Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Prophetic literature concerning the "Day of the Lord" has seismic shaking in Isaiah 2:19</li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.2?lang=bi">sefaria.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.2?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah Chapter 5 - English and Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/scriptureotherar0000unse/page/196/mode/2up">
Freedman and Welch (1994:196)</a> suggest that <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.5.25?lang=bi">Isaiah 5:25</a> <q>appears to be a direct reference
to the quake in Uzziah's day.</q></li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.5?lang=bi">sefaria.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.5?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Isaiah Chapter 6 - English and Hebrew
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/scriptureotherar0000unse/page/196/mode/2up">
Freedman and Welch (1994:196)</a> suggest that <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.6.4?lang=bi">Isaiah 6:4</a>
<q>may reflect <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.9.1?lang=bi">Amos 9:1</a></q></li>
<li>Isaiah 6 contains a prophetic vision that has Temple Shaking in verse
4. In verse 1, Isaiah states that he had this vision in the year that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a>
died - which according to Thiele's chronology was in 740/739 BCE</li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.6?lang=bi">sefaria.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.6?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">


<tr>
<th>Year</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>768/767 - 751/750 BCE<br>(Thiele's chronology)</td>
<td><q>For as the mountains shook when the glory of the Lord was revealed in the days of Uzziah the King</q> (Targum Isaiah 28:21)</td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a>
<ul>
<li>William F. Albright dates Uzziah's reign to 783–742 BC.(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
<li>Edwin R. Thiele's chronology has Uzziah becoming coregent with
his father Amaziah in 792/791 BCE and sole ruler of Judah after
his father's death in 768/767 BCE. Uzziah was struck with leprosy
for disobeying God (2 Kings 15:5, 2 Chronicles 26:19–21).
Thiele dates Uzziah's being struck with leprosy to 751/750 BCE,
at which time his son Jotham took over the government, with Uzziah
living on until 740/739 BCE. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pekah">Pekah</a> became king of Israel in
the last year of Uzziah's reign. (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>If we use Theile's chronology, Uzziah ruled (as a sole ruler) between the
years of 768/767 and 751/750 BCE.</li>
<li>References
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/1355182">
Albright, W. F. (1945). "The Chronology of the Divided Monarchy of Israel."
Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research 100: 16-22.</a></li>
<li><a href="https://archive.org/details/mysteriousnumber0000thie">
Thiele, E. R. (1983). The Mysterious Numbers of the Hebrew Kings, Academic Books.</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>


</table>

<h7>Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li><q>the mountains shook</q></li>
<li>Damage to buildings and fallen trees in Samaria - see collapsible panel titled Building Damage in Samaria</li>
</ul>

<h7>Locations</h7>

<ul>
<li>Judea</li>
<li>Samaria - see collapsible panel titled Building Damage in Samaria</li>
</ul>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Building Damage in Samaria
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

<a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_in_the/5TZXAQAAQBAJ?hl=en">
Schoors (2013:56)</a> states that <q>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strophe">strophe</a> in <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.9.8?lang=bi">[Isaiah] 9:8–11</a>
recalls the earthquakes that struck Palestine during Uzziah’s reign
(cf. <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.1.1?lang=bi">Amos 1:1</a>)</q>.<br><br>


<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">
Austin et al. (2000:659)</a> concur

<blockquote>
The biblical records indicate that Samaria received severe damage to palace-fortresses, walls, and houses
(Amos <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.3.11?lang=bi">3:11</a> [JW: seems to allude to destruction by war not an earthquake];
<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.4.3?lang=bi">4:3</a> [JW: seems to allude to the Assyrian conquest(s) not an earthquake];
<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Amos.6.11?lang=bi">6:11</a> [JW: This could refer to an earthquake]).
Pride in Israel's royal citadel and fear of an Assyrian invasion would have been incentives for Samaria to upgrade quickly from the
fallen mud brick to stronger hewn stone (<a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Isaiah.9.10?lang=bi">Isaiah 9:9,10</a>
[JW: This appears to discuss rebuilding in Samaria after earthquake damage]
<a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Hebrews%209&version=NIV">Heb. 9:8,9</a>
[JW: I don't see how Heb. 9:8,9 is related to destruction in Samaria - this chapter is describing the original <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabernacle">Tabernacle</a>]).
</blockquote>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Online Versions and Further Reading</h7>

International Geology Review 42(7): 657-671.</a><br><br>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="Josephus">Jewish Antiquities by Josephus</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>
<h7>Background and Biography</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Background and Biography</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Josephus.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Josephus"></iframe>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English Translation of Jewish Antiquities by Whiston (1737)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Jewish Antiquities Book 9 Chapter 10 Paragraph 4</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/CompleteWorksOfJosephusTranslatedByWilliamWhiston1737/page/n659/mode/2up">Whiston (1737)</a></li>
</ul>

4. While <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">Uzziah</a> was in this state,
and making preparation [for futurity], he was corrupted in his mind by pride,
and became insolent, and this on account of that abundance which he had of things that will soon perish, and
despised that power which is of eternal duration (which consisted in piety towards God, and in the observation
of the laws); so he fell by occasion of the good success of his affairs, and was carried headlong into those
sins of his father, which the splendor of that prosperity he enjoyed, and the glorious actions he had done,
led him into, while he was not able to govern himself well about them. Accordingly, when a remarkable day was
come, and a general festival was to be celebrated, he put on the holy garment, and went into the temple to
offer incense to God upon the golden altar, which he was prohibited to do by
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azariah_II">Azariah</a> the high priest, who
had fourscore priests with him, and who told him that it was not lawful for him to offer sacrifice, and
that "none besides the posterity of Aaron were permitted so to do." And when they cried out that he must
go out of the temple, and not transgress against God, he was wroth at them, and threatened to kill them,
unless they would hold their peace. <b>In the mean time a great earthquake shook the ground<sup>21</sup> and a rent was
made in the temple, and the bright rays of the sun shone through it, and fell upon the king's face, insomuch
that the leprosy seized upon him immediately</b>. And before the city, at a place called Eroge
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">likely Ein Rogel in Silwan on the outskirts of the border of what was then Jerusalem)</a>),
half the mountain broke off from the rest on the west, and rolled itself four furlongs
(<a href="https://www.unitjuggler.com/convert-length-from-stadium-to-km.html?val=4">0.75 km.</a>),
and stood still at the east mountain,
till the roads, as well as the king's gardens, were spoiled by the obstruction. Now, as soon as the priests
saw that the king's face was infected with the leprosy, they told him of the calamity he was under, and
commanded that he should go out of the city as a polluted person. Hereupon he was so confounded at the sad
distemper, and sensible that he was not at liberty to contradict, that he did as he was commanded, and
underwent this miserable and terrible punishment for an intention beyond what befitted a man to have,
and for that impiety against God which was implied therein. So he abode out of the city for some time,
and lived a private life, while his son <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a>
took the government; after which he died with grief and
anxiety at what had happened to him, when he had lived sixty-eight years, and reigned of them fifty-two;
and was buried by himself in his own gardens.


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


(21) This account of an earthquake at Jerusalem at the very same time when Uzziah usurped the priest's office,
and went into the sanctuary to burn incense, and of the consequences of the earthquake, is entirely wanting in
our other copies, though it be exceeding like to a prophecy of Jeremiah, now in Zechariah 14:4,-5; in which
prophecy mention is made of "fleeing from that earthquake, as they fled from this earthquake in the days of
Uzziah king of Judah;" so that there seems to have been some considerable resemblance between these historical
and prophetical earthquakes.

</p>
</div>
</div>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Greek from Niese (1892)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Jewish Antiquities Book 9 Chapter 10 Sections 222-227</li>
<li>from <a href="http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0145%3Abook%3D9%3Asection%3D222">Niese (1892)</a></li>
</ul>



<font size="+1">

[222] Γενόμενος δ᾽ ἐν ταύτῃ τῇ συντάξει καὶ παρασκευῇ διεφθάρη τὴν διάνοιαν ὑπὸ τύφου καὶ χαυνωθεὶς θνητῇ περιουσίᾳ τῆς
ἀθανάτου καὶ πρὸς ἅπαντα διαρκοῦς τὸν χρόνον ἰσχύος ὠλιγώρησεν: αὕτη δὲ ἦν ἡ πρὸς τὸν θεὸν εὐσέβεια καὶ τὸ τηρεῖν τὰ νόμιμα.
[223] ὤλισθε δὲ ὑπ᾽ εὐπραξίας καὶ κατηνέχθη πρὸς τὰ τοῦ πατρὸς ἁμαρτήματα, πρὸς ἃ κἀκεῖνον ἡ τῶν ἀγαθῶν λαμπρότης καὶ τὸ
μέγεθος τῶν πραγμάτων οὐ δυνηθέντα προστῆναι καλῶς αὐτῶν ἤγαγεν. ἐνστάσης δ᾽ ἡμέρας ἐπισήμου καὶ πάνδημον ἑορτὴν ἐχούσης
ἐνδὺς ἱερατικὴν στολὴν εἰσῆλθεν εἰς τὸ τέμενος θυσιάσων ἐπὶ τοῦ χρυσοῦ βωμοῦ τῷ θεῷ. [224] τοῦ δ᾽ ἀρχιερέως Ἀζαρία ὄντων
σὺν αὐτῷ ἱερέων ὀγδοήκοντα κωλύοντος αὐτόν, οὐ γὰρ ἐξὸν ἐπιθύειν εἶπον, μόνοις δ᾽ ἐφεῖσθαι τοῦτο ποιεῖν τοῖς ἐκ τοῦ Ἀαρῶνος
γένους, καταβοώντων δ᾽ ἐξιέναι καὶ μὴ παρανομεῖν εἰς τὸν θεόν, ὀργισθεὶς ἠπείλησεν αὐτοῖς θάνατον, εἰ μὴ τὴν ἡσυχίαν ἄξουσι.
[225] μεταξὺ δὲ σεισμὸς ἐκλόνησε τὴν γῆν μέγας καὶ διαστάντος τοῦ ναοῦ φέγγος ἡλίου λαμπρὸν ἐξέλαμψε καὶ τῇ τοῦ βασιλέως
ὄψει προσέπεσεν, ὡς τῷ μὲν εὐθέως λέπραν ἐπιδραμεῖν, πρὸ δὲ τῆς πόλεως πρὸς τῇ καλουμένῃ Ἐρωγῇ τοῦ ὄρους ἀπορραγῆναι τὸ
ἥμισυ τοῦ κατὰ τὴν δύσιν καὶ κυλισθὲν τέσσαρας σταδίους ἐπὶ τὸ ἀνατολικὸν ὄρος στῆναι, ὡς τάς τε παρόδους ἐμφραγῆναι καὶ
τοὺς παραδείσους τοὺς βασιλικούς. [226] ἐπεὶ δὲ κατειλημμένην τὴν ὄψιν τοῦ βασιλέως ὑπὸ τῆς λέπρας εἶδον οἱ ἱερεῖς,
ἔφραζόν τε αὐτῷ τὴν συμφορὰν καὶ ἐκέλευον ἐξιέναι τῆς πόλεως ὡς ἐναγῆ. ὁ δ᾽ ὑπ᾽ αἰσχύνης τε τοῦ συμβεβηκότος δεινοῦ
καὶ τοῦ μηκέτ᾽ αὐτῷ παρρησίαν εἶναι τὸ κελευόμενον ἐποίει, τῆς ὑπὲρ ἄνθρωπον διανοίας καὶ τῶν διὰ τοῦτο εἰς τὸν θεὸν
ἀσεβημάτων ταλαίπωρον οὕτως καὶ οἰκτρὰν ὑπομείνας δίκην. [227] καὶ χρόνον μέν τινα διῆγεν ἔξω τῆς πόλεως
ἰδιώτην ἀποζῶν βίον τοῦ παιδὸς αὐτῷ Ἰωθάμου τὴν ἀρχὴν παραλαβόντος, ἔπειτα ὑπὸ λύπης καὶ ἀθυμίας τῆς ἐπὶ τοῖς
γεγενημένοις ἀπέθανεν, ἔτη μὲν βιώσας ὀκτὼ καὶ ἑξήκοντα, τούτων δὲ βασιλεύσας πεντηκονταδύο. ἐκηδεύθη δὲ μόνος
ἐν τοῖς ἑαυτοῦ κήποις.


</font>



</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English Translation of Jewish Antiquities by Whiston (1737) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Jewish Antiquities Book 9 Chapter 10 Paragraph 4</li>
<li>see bottom paragraph on right page</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/CompleteWorksOfJosephusTranslatedByWilliamWhiston1737/page/n659/mode/2up">Whiston (1737)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/CompleteWorksOfJosephusTranslatedByWilliamWhiston1737/page/n659/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
</ul>

<iframe src="https://archive.org/details/CompleteWorksOfJosephusTranslatedByWilliamWhiston1737/page/n659/mode/2up"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">
<caption><b>Jewish Antiquities</b></caption>

<tr>
<th>Date</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>750/751 BCE<br>(Thiele's chronology)</td>
<td><q>a great earthquake shook the ground and a rent was made in the temple, and the bright rays of the sun shone through it,
and fell upon the king's [Uzziah] face, insomuch that the leprosy seized upon him immediately</q></td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>Josephus synchronizes the earthquake with the onset of leprosy in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a></li>
<li><q>Thiele dates <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> being struck with leprosy to 751/750 BCE,
at which time his son <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a> took over the government</q>
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
<li><a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt09b15.htm#5">2 Kings 15:5</a> and
<a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt25b26.htm#19">2 Chronicles 26:19-21</a> discuss how
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> was struck with leprosy but do not synchronize this with an earthquake.
<a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt25b26.htm#19">2 Chronicles 26:19-20</a> (written later than 2 Kings and using 2 Kings as some of its source material)
does, however, synchronize Uzziah's unlawful actions at the Temple with the recognition of leprosy on the face of the King.</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>

</table>


<h7>Seismic Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li><q>a great earthquake shook the ground</q></li>
<li><q>a rent was made in the temple</q></li>
<li>landslide - <q>before the city, at a place called Eroge
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">likely Ein Rogel in Silwan on the outskirts of the border of what was then Jerusalem</a>), half the mountain
broke off from the rest on the west, and rolled itself four furlongs
(<a href="https://www.unitjuggler.com/convert-length-from-stadium-to-km.html?val=4">0.75 km.</a>), and stood still at the east mountain,
till the roads, as well as the king's gardens, were spoiled by the obstruction.</q></li>
</ul>

<h7>Locations mentioned</h7>

<ul>
<li>The Temple in Jerusalem</li>
<li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">Ein Rogel (near Jerusalem)</a> (Eroge in the text)</li>
</ul>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Location of Ein-Rogel
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/Ambraseys2009.html">Ambraseys (2009)</a> notes

<blockQuote>
As for the location of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ein_Rogel">En-rogel</a>, it has been suggested that it is the
fountain of the Virgin, the modern Ain Umm al-Daraj. Others identify it with Bir Eyub, to the south of the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pool_of_Siloam">Pool of Siloam</a>, and
below the junction of the valleys of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kidron_Valley">Kidron</a> and
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valley_of_Hinnom_(Gehenna)">Hinnom</a>,
which seems to be a more probable location, but again this is not certain.
</blockquote>

Some websites discussing Ein-Rogel are listed below

<ul>
<li><a href="https://bibleatlas.org/en-rogel.htm">bibleatlas.org</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/resources/encyclopedia-of-the-bible/En-Rogel">biblegateway.com</a></li>
<li><a href="https://classic.net.bible.org/dictionary.php?word=En%20Rogel">classic.net,bible.org</a></li>
</ul>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="AvotRabbiNathan">Avot de-Rabbi Nathan</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>


<h7>Background and Biography</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Background and Biography</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/AvotRabbiNathan.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="AvotRabbiNathan"></iframe>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English of version A (traditional) from Goldin (1955)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Chapter 9</li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Fathers_According_to_Rabbi_Nathan/YXgPAQAAIAAJ?hl=enl">
Goldin (1955:56-57)</a></li>
</ul>


CHAPTER 9<br><br>

NITTAI THE ARBELITE SAYS: KEEP FAR AWAY FROM AN EVIL NEIGHBOR, DO NOT ASSOCIATE WITH THE WICKED, AND DO NOT LOSE HOPE OF THE FINAL RECKONING.<sup>1</sup><br><br>

... Rabbi Simeon ben Eleazar says: So, too,.<sup>28</sup> on them that speak slander plagues come. For thus we find concerning
Gehazi that he told a lying tale.<sup>29</sup> about his master and leprosy clove to him until the day of his death,
as it is said, The leprosy therefore of Naaman shall cleave unto thee . . . and he went out from his
presence a leper as white as snow (II Kings 5: 27).<br><br>

He used to say: Upon the arrogant of spirit plagues come. For thus we find concerning Uzziah, as it is said,
But when he was strong, his heart was lifted up so that he did corruptly, and he trespassed.<sup>30</sup> against the Lord his God;
for he went into the temple of the Lord to burn incense upon the altar of incense. And Azariah the priest went in
after him, and with him fourscore priests of the Lord, that were valiant men; and they withstood Uzziah the king,
and said unto him: It pertaineth not unto thee, Uzziah, to burn incense unto the Lord, but to the priests,
the sons of Aaron, that are consecrated, it pertaineth to burn incense;.<sup>31</sup> go out of the sanctuary; for thou hast trespassed;
neither shall it be for thy honor from the Lord God. Then Uzziah was wroth; and he had a censer in his hand to burn incense;
and while he was wroth with the priests, the leprosy broke forth in his forehead (II Chron. 26: 16-19).<br><br>

<b>At that time the sanctuary split in two parts, leaving a cleft of twelve miles</b>;.<sup>32</sup> and the priests thrust him out quickly,
Yea, himself made haste also to go out, because the Lord had smitten him. And he.<sup>33</sup> was a leper unto the day of his death,
and dwelt in a house set apart, being a leper; for he was cut off from the house of the Lord; and I tham his son was
over the king's house, judging the people of the land (II Chron. 26: 20-21).

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


1. PA I: 7; Cf. ARNB, p. 35.<br><br>

28. Cf., however, ARNS, p. 41, n. 36; ARNB, Ch. 16, p. 36.<br><br>

29. Literally, "slander."<br><br>

30. Text adds ma'al; cf. MT.<br><br>

31. Text: lehaktiro; cf. MT.<br><br>

32. Literally, "in two parts, twelve by twelve miles." See Legends, 6, 358, n. 30.<br><br>

33. Cf. MT.<br><br>




</p>
</div>
</div>




</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English of version A (traditional) from Guidoboni et al (1994)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Chapter 9</li>
<li>from <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/GuidoboniEtAl1994.html">
Guidoboni et al (1994)</a></li>
</ul>

Chapter 9<br><br>

...<br><br>

In connection with Uzziah we find [written (2 Chron. 26.16-7)]: <br><br>

'But when he gained power, his heart grew so proud that it caused his downfall. For he transgressed against
the Lord his God and went into the sanctuary of the Lord to offer incense on the altar of perfumes. He was
followed there by the priest Azaryahu with eighty courageous priests of the Lord. They stood before king
Uzziyahu and said to him:

<blockquote>
'It is not for you, Uzziyahu, to offer incense to the Lord, but for the priests
who are sons of Aaron and who were consecrated to offer incense. Leave the sanctuary, for you have sinned
and your reputation before the Lord God will not be improved by it'.
</blockquote>

Uzziyahu grew angry, as he held the
censer in his hand, and at the moment of his irritation with the priests, leprosy appeared on his brow'.
<b>At the same moment the temple split open and the fissure extended for twelve miles in each direction</b>.
The priests made him leave, and he himself hurried to depart because the Lord had struck him. [King Uzziyahu]
remained a leper until his death, and lived in a leper house, because he had been sent away from the house of
the Lord. Meanwhile, his son Jotham supervised the royal palace and administered justice to the people of the country.


</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English of Version B from Saldarini (1975)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Version B referred to as ARNB is not the traditional version of this text</li>
<li>An earthquake is not mentioned in version B but leprosy is</li>
<li>Chapter 16</li>
<li>Can be borrowed with a free account from archive.org</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/fathersaccording0000unse/page/112/mode/2up">Saldarini (1975:112-114)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/fathersaccording0000unse/page/112/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
</ul>


CHAPTER SIXTEEN<br><br>

RABBI JOSHUA BEN PERAHYAH AND NITTAI THE ARBELITE TOOK OVER FROM THEM.<sup>1</sup>
RABBI JOSHUA BEN PERAHYAH SAYS:<sup>2</sup> FLEE FROM AN EVIL NEIGHBOR, DO NOT ASSOCIATE WITH THE WICKED,
AND DO NOT SHRUG OFF ALL THOUGHT OF CALAMITY.<sup>3</sup><br><br>

...<br><br>

Rabbi Simeon says : Plagues only come because of slander, and
leprosy only comes because of haughtiness,<sup>7</sup> as Scripture says:
"But when he [King Uzziah] was strong he grew proud, to his destruction.
For he was false to the Lord his God, and entered the temple of the Lord
to burn incense on the alter of incense. But Azariah the priest went in
after him, with eighty priests of the Lord who were men of valor ; and they
withstood King Uzziah, and said to him, `It is not for you, Uzziah, to burn
incense to the Lord, but for the priests the sons of Aaron, who are
consecrated to burn incense. Go out of the sanctuary; for you have done
wrong, and it will bring you no honor from the Lord God.' Then Uzziah was angry.
Now he had a censer in his hand to burn incense, and when he became angry with
the priests, leprosy broke out on his forehead, in the presence of the priests
in the house of the Lord, by the altar of incense. And Azariah the chief priests,
and all the priests, looked at him, and behold, he was leprous
in his forehead! And they thrust him out quickly, and he himself hastened to go out,
because the Lord had smitten him. And King Uzziah was a leper to the day of his death...
(2 Chr. 26:16-21)." And Uzziah the king (lived) twenty-five years (as a leper).<sup>8</sup>



<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


1. Ms. R and Schechter's edition omit this first sentence, but Ms. P (Schechter, p. 169) has it.
It dropped out through homoeoteleuton between the two mentions of Joshua's name.<br><br>

2 Joshua and Nittai were the second pair and flourished during the second half of the second century, B.C.
Joshua had to flee to Alexandria to escape John Hyrcanus (Weiss, Dor, I, p. 133). See PA 1:6 and ARNA p. 35 (G p. 49).<br><br>

3 The sayings of Joshua and Nittai have been switched in B (as compared to PA and ARNA). This switch suggests
a possible disturbance in the text in Version B. Similarly, the sayings of the next pair are switched, in Ch. 20 (p. 42) below.<br><br>


7. The causes of leprosy are a recurring theme in rabbinic literature. Here Rabbi Simeon distinguishes plagues
(ng`m) and leprosy (qr`t) and specifies the transgressions which cause them. Then the story of Uzziah is told
as an example of haughtiness causing leprosy. The Hebrew term for haughtiness (gbh rwh) is taken from 2 Chr. 26:16.
Ms. H has gsy hrwh, a term similar to the one which occurs in the sources mentioned below. Ms. P : gbhy rwh;
Ms. N : gbhwt hrwh. Slander causes plagues. See also LevRab 18:4 (Margulies, p. 409).<br><br>

ARNA has two passages similar to this one : p. 39 (G p. 54) and p. 41 (G pp. 56-57). In the first Rabbi
Simeon says that plagues come from slander and adduces the example of Miriam and Aaron in Num. 12.
In the second Rabbi Simeon ben Eleazar says the same and then adduces the example of Gehazi lying and contracting
Naaman's leprosy (2 Ki. 5:27). Rabbi Simeon then says that plagues come upon the haughty and adduces the example of Uzziah.<br><br>

Slander is said to cause leprosy and the example of Miriam and Aaron is adduced in ARNB p. 116 (end of Ch. 41) and in
SifreDt 275 (Finkelstein, p. 294).<br><br>

Rabbi Simeon is usually Rabbi Simeon ben Johai, a member of the third generation of Tannaim and a pupil of Akiba.
But if A's final attribution is accurate, Rabbi Simeon is ben Eleazar, of the fourth generation (end of the second century),
a pupil of Meir and contemporary of Rabbi.<br><br>

Several rabbinic passages give the reasons for which leprosy comes. LevRab 17:3 (Margulies, p. 374ff) gives ten reasons,
among them haughtiness (gsy hrwh) with Uzziah as example and slander (lkwn hr`) with Aaron and Miriam as example.
Arakin 16a gives seven reasons including haughtiness (gswt hrwh) with Uzziah as example and slander followed by the
quoting of Ps. 101:5. In NumRab 7:5 eleven reasons are given. Haughtiness (gswt hrwh) is one, but Naaman (2 Ki. 5:1)
is the example. Uzziah is connected with the sin of encroaching on another's domain (that is, unauthorized entry into
the temple). Uzziah occurs under the same heading in Tan, Mesora', 4 and TanBub, Lev., pp. 48-49 where eleven things are
again given. Haughtiness does not occur, but slander is given with the example of Miriam and Aaron.<br><br>

8 Seder Olam Rabba 19, end, like ARNB, says that Uzziah lived for twenty-five years after contracting leprosy.
TosSot 12:4 says that Jotham, his son, judged Israel all the years he had leprosy (that is, Jotham was co-regent).<br><br>

For the years of Uzziah and Jotham see 2 Chr. 26-27 and 2 Ki 15. He was twenty-five when he began to reign (2 Ki. 15:33).
Why ARNB and Seder Olam say Uzziah was twenty-five years leprous is not clear. Perhaps they connected this with Jotham's
birth (for he was twenty-five at Uzziah's death). See Schechter, n. 6, who says it is a digression. Actually, the sentence
at least shows how severe the penalty is for being haughty.<br><br>


</p>
</div>
</div>



</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English of Version B from Saldarini (1975) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Version B referred to as ARNB is not the traditional version of this text</li>
<li>An earthquake is not mentioned in this version (version B) but leprosy is</li>
<li>Chapter 16</li>
<li>Can be borrowed with a free account from archive.org</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/fathersaccording0000unse/page/112/mode/2up">Saldarini (1975:113-114)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/fathersaccording0000unse/page/112/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://archive.org/details/fathersaccording0000unse/page/112/mode/2upp#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>




</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Hebrew of versions A and B from Schechter (1887) - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>requires that your browser has a pdf reader</li>
<li>not bookmarked</li>
<li><a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Fathers_According_to_Rabbi_Nathan/YXgPAQAAIAAJ?hl=enl">
Goldin (1955:xxiii)</a> and <a href="https://archive.org/details/fathersaccording0000unse/page/112/mode/2up">
Saldarini (1975:14)</a> both state that Schechter (1887)'s edition has versions A and B in parallel columns.</li>
<li>from <a href="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2d/Avot-de-Rabbi-Natan-Schechter-1887-HB38247.pdf">Schechter (1887)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2d/Avot-de-Rabbi-Natan-Schechter-1887-HB38247.pdf">wikipedia</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2d/Avot-de-Rabbi-Natan-Schechter-1887-HB38247.pdf#"

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">

<tr>
<th>Date</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>750/751 BCE<br>(Thiele's chronology)</td>
<td><q>the temple split open and the fissure extended for twelve miles in each direction</q></td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>The traditional version (version A) of Avot de-Rabbi Nathan Chapter 9 synchronizes the earthquake with the onset of
leprosy in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a></li>
<li><q>Thiele dates <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> being struck with leprosy to 751/750 BCE,
at which time his son <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a> took over the government</q>
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
<li><a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt09b15.htm#5">2 Kings 15:5</a> and
<a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt25b26.htm#19">2 Chronicles 26:19-21</a> discuss how
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> was struck with leprosy but do not synchronize this with an earthquake.
<a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt25b26.htm#19">2 Chronicles 26:19-20</a> (written later than 2 Kings and using 2 Kings as some of its source material)
does, however, synchronize Uzziah's unlawful actions at the Temple with the recognition of leprosy on the face of the King.</li>
<li>Another version (version B - not the traditional version) translated by
<a href="https://archive.org/details/fathersaccording0000unse/page/112/mode/2up">Saldarini (1975:113-114)</a>
includes the leprosy but does not include an earthquake</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>

</table>

<h7>Seismic Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li><q>At that time the sanctuary split in two parts, leaving a cleft of twelve miles</q> -
literally <q>in two parts, twelve by twelve miles</q></li>
</ul>

<h7>Locations</h7>

<ul>
<li>First Temple in Jerusalem</li>
</ul>

<h7>Background and Biography</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Background</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Midrash.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Midrash"></iframe>

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Midrash Tanchuma, Noach 5 (Tanchuma A aka Tanchuma Buber) in English and Hebrew - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/GuidoboniEtAl1994.html">Guidoboni et al (1994)</a> noted to
<q>See also <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanhuma">Midrash Tanhuma</a> to Noah, chapter 5</q>. Although Amos is quoted in version B
(aka Midrash Tanchuma Yelammedenu) of this text (<a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+2&version=NIV">Amos 2:6</a>), the part of Amos mentioning the earthquake is not quoted
and there does not seem to be any allusions to an earthquake. There is no mention of Amos or an earthquake in version A (aka Midrash Tanchuma Buber)</li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Midrash_Tanchuma_Buber%2C_Noach.5?lang=bi">Midrash Tanchuma, Noach 5</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Midrash_Tanchuma_Buber%2C_Noach.5?lang=bi">sefaria.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Midrash_Tanchuma_Buber%2C_Noach.5?lang=bii#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Midrash Tanchuma, Noach 5 (Tanchuma B aka Yelammedenu) in English and Hebrew - embedded
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li><a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/GuidoboniEtAl1994.html">Guidoboni et al (1994)</a> noted to
<q>See also <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanhuma">Midrash Tanhuma</a> to Noah, chapter 5</q>. Although Amos is quoted in version B
(aka Midrash Tanchuma Yelammedenu) of this text (<a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+2&version=NIV">Amos 2:6</a>), the part of Amos mentioning the earthquake is not quoted
and there does not seem to be any allusions to an earthquake. There is no mention of Amos or an earthquake in version A (aka Midrash Tanchuma Buber)</li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Midrash_Tanchuma%2C_Noach.5.1?lang=bi">Midrash Tanchuma, Noach 5</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://www.sefaria.org/Midrash_Tanchuma%2C_Noach.5.1?lang=bi">sefaria.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://www.sefaria.org/Midrash_Tanchuma%2C_Noach.5.1?lang=bi#"
height="1000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" ></iframe><br><br>

</p>

<h7>Chronology</h7><br><br>

<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/GuidoboniEtAl1994.html">Guidoboni et al (1994)</a> noted to
<q>See also <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanhuma">Midrash Tanhuma</a> to Noah, chapter 5</q>. Although Amos is quoted in version B
(aka Midrash Tanchuma Yelammedenu) of this text (<a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+2&version=NIV">Amos 2:6</a>), the part of Amos mentioning the earthquake is not quoted
and there does not seem to be any allusions to an earthquake. There is no mention of Amos or an earthquake in version A (aka Midrash Tanchuma Buber).<br><br>


<h7>Seismic Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li>an earthquake is not mentioned</li>
</ul>

<h7>Locations</h7>

<ul>
<li>none specified</li>
</ul>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="Jerome">Jerome's Commentary on Amos</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>


<h7>Background and Biography</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Biography</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/Jerome.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Jerome"></iframe>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
English from Soenksen and Scheck (2017)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>Jerome's commentary on Amos (PL, vol. 25, col. 992)</li>
<li>from <a href="https://books.google.com/books?id=OzpS492yf74C">Soenksen and Scheck (2017:302-303)</a></li>
</ul>

1:1b In the days of Uzziah, king of Judah, and in the days of Jeroboam, son of Joash, king of Israel, two years before the earthquake.<br><br>

[This was the time] when Sardanapalus was ruling among the Assyrians and the cities of Cilicia. One noteworthy author says this about him:
"He was baser in his vices than in his name."<sup>13</sup> And among the Latins, Procas Silvius [was ruling]. His son Amulius succeeded to the throne
after his brother, Numitor, was banished. After Amulius was killed, a band of shepherds and thieves gathered together, and Romulus
founded the city that bears his name. Now this is <b>Uzziah, also called Azariah,<sup>14</sup> the king of Judah, who tried to claim the priesthood
as his right and was afflicted with leprosy on his forehead.<sup>15</sup> Not only the punishment of this sacrilegious man, but the earthquake, too,
which the Hebrews remember happened then, showed the anger of God</b>.<br><br>

...<br><br>

In the days of Uzziah, the king of Judah, the strength of the Lord remained there because of the temple and the holy of holies,
and he ruled the confessing people by his own authority. But the name Jeroboam, who had emerged because of the division of the people,
indicates that Israel remained for a long time in the error of idolatry, before a universal captivity shook them violently.
In two years this idolatry manifested a twofold distress, for the ten tribes and for the other two. <b>The purpose of this distress
was that, if they were willing, they might not experience an earthquake in the future by repenting</b>.




<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

13 Cf. Cicero, De republica 3, frag. 4.<br><br>

14 CE 2 Kings 15:1-2. <br><br>

15 CE 2 Chron 26:16-23. <br><br>




</p>
</div>
</div>



</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Latin from Migne (1849)
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li>from <a href="http://www.documentacatholicaomnia.eu/02m/0347-0420,_Hieronymus,_Commentariorum_In_Amos_Prophetam_Libri_Tres,_MLT.pdf">Migne (1849)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="http://www.documentacatholicaomnia.eu/02m/0347-0420,_Hieronymus,_Commentariorum_In_Amos_Prophetam_Libri_Tres,_MLT.pdf">documentacatholicaomnia.eu</a></li>
</ul>

In diebus Oziae regis Juda, et in diebus Jeroboam fili Joas regis Israel, ante duos annos terrae motus.<br><br>


Quando apud Assyrios urbesqueCiliciae regnabat
Sardanapalus, de quo insignis orator : Turpier, inquit, vitiis, quam nomine. Et apud Latinos Procas Silvius, cui Amulius, expulso Numitore
germano, successit in regnum. Quo interfecto, congregata pastorum et latronum manu, Romulus sui nominis condidit civitatem. Hic est
autem Ozias rex Juda, cognomento Azarias, qui indebitum sibi sacerdotium vindicare conatus, lepra percussus in fronte est (III Paral. xxvi),
quando iram Domini non solum poena ejus, qui sacrilegus fuit; sed et terrae motas ostendit, quem Hebraei tunc accidisse commemorant.<br><br>

...<br><br>

In diebus Oziae regis Juda, in quo propter templum et sancta sanctorum, fortitudo Domini permanebat, suoque regebat imperio populum
confitentem. Nomen autem Jeroboam, qui divisionis populi causa extiterat, signifiat Israelem longo tempore in idololatriae [224] errore
mansisse, priusquam captivitas universa concuteret, quae in duobus annis duplicem ostendit angustiam decem tribuum, ac duarum:
et agentes, si vellen!, poenitentiam, motum terrae de caetero non sentirent.<br><br>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">

<tr>
<th>Date</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>750/751 BCE<br>(Thiele's chronology)</td>
<td><q>Now this is Uzziah, also called Azariah, the king of Judah, who tried to claim the priesthood
as his right and was afflicted with leprosy on his forehead. Not only the punishment of this sacrilegious man, but the earthquake, too,
which the Hebrews remember happened then, showed the anger of God</q></td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>The earthquake is synchronized with the day <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a>
contracted leprosy.</li>
<li><q>Thiele dates <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> being struck with leprosy to 751/750 BCE,
at which time his son <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a> took over the government</q>
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>

</table>

<h7>Seismic Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li><q>the earthquake, too, which the Hebrews remember happened then, showed the anger of God</q></li>
</ul>

<h7>Locations</h7>

<ul>
<li>Although Jerome does not specifically mention damage to the 1st Temple due to the earthquake, the context of the
account indicates that the earthquake was experienced at the 1st Temple in Jerusalem</li>
</ul>

Migne, ed., Libri Commentariorum, PL vol. 25, coll. 989-1096C.</a> - Jerome's Commentary on Amos in Latin<br><br>

Scheck, Thomas P. ed. (2017). Commentary on the Twelve Prophets, Volume 2 Jerome, Catholic University of America Press.</a><br><br>

<a href="https://www.roger-pearse.com/weblog/2015/06/29/translations-of-the-biblical-commentaries-of-st-jerome/">
