<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="LegendsOfTheJews">Legends of the Jews by Ginzberg</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>


<h7>Background and Biography</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Background</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/AuthorBios/LegendsOfTheJews.html"
height="500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Legends of the Jews"></iframe>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<h7>Excerpts</h7>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Legends of the Jews volume 4 by Ginzberg (1936) in English translation
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">
Austin et al (2000:663)</a> state that <q>details of the earthquake and landslide, as described by Josephus, are independently supported by very old
traditions of the rabbis (Ginzberg, 1936, p. 262)</q>. The relevant extract from <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">
Ginzberg (1936:262)</a> and it's accompanying footnotes indicates a complicated provenance which includes Josephus and some Christian sources in addition to
Rabbinic sources.</li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">Ginzberg (1936:262)</a></li>
<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
</ul>

However, the fearlessness of Amos finally caused his death. King Uzziah inflicted a mortal blow upon his forehead with a red-hot iron.<sup>28</sup><br><br>

Two years after Amos ceased to prophesy, Isaiah was favored with his first Divine communication. It was the day on which King Uzziah,
blinded by success and prosperity, arrogated to himself the privileges of the priesthood. He tried to offer sacrifices upon the altar,
and when the high priest Azariah<sup>29</sup> ventured to restrain him, he threatened to slay him and any priest sympathizing with him unless
they kept silent. Suddenly the earth quaked so violently that a great breach was torn in the Temple, through which a brilliant ray of
sunlight pierced, falling upon the forehead of the king and causing leprosy to break forth upon him. Nor was that all the damage done
by the earthquake. On the west side of Jerusalem, half of the mountain was split off and hurled to the east, into a road, at a
distance of four stadia.<sup>30</sup> And not heaven and earth alone were outraged by Uzziah’s atrocity and sought to annihilate him ; even the angels
of fire, the seraphim, were on the point of descending and consuming him, when a voice from on high proclaimed, that the punishment
appointed for Uzziah was unlike that meted out to Korah and his company despite the similarity of their crimes.<sup>31</sup>
<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
Footnotes
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>

<uL>
<li>Footnotes come from <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0006ginz_b8e2/page/356/mode/2up">Volume 6 (357-358) (bookmarked)</a></li>
</ul>

28 Yahya, Shalshelet ha-Kabbalah, 97, undoubtedly based on a Christian source; comp. note 25. According to ps.-Epiphanius, De Vitis Prophetarum, s. v. "Amos",
this prophet met his death through a blow on his temples dealt him with a stick by the son of the false prophet Amaziah. Comp. Index, s. v. "Amaziah, Priest of Beth-el".<br><br>

29 Azariah the "chief priest" in 2 Chron. 26.20, is identified with Azariah the high priest, in 1 Chron. 5.36. Comp. Sifre Z., 112, and Josephus, Antiqui., IX, 10.4.
The Rabbis maintain that chapter 6 of Isaiah is the beginning of this prophetic book, and contains the first vision granted to the prophet on the day on which the
impious king Uzziah attempted to sacrifice on the altar and was stricken with leprosy. As a "leper is like dead" (comp. note 177 on vol. I, p. 364), מות in Is. 6.1
does not mean death but leprosy. See Targum, ad loc.; ShR 1.34; Tan. Zaw 13. Comp. also Seder `Olam 20; Mekilta Shirah 6 (beginning); Yelammedenu in Yalkut II, 404 on Is. 6; Aphraates,
362 (read אדעא instead of עמא); Jerome on Is. 7.3, seq.; ps.- Jerome on 2 Chron. 26.22.<br><br>
30 Josephus, Antigui„ IX, 10.4. Tan. Noah 13 is not contented with a breach in the Temple; it says that the hall of the Temple (היבל) was rent in two parts, separated from each other
by a cleft of twelve miles (a favorite number; see Index) in width, and the Midrash transfers to the Temple itself that which Josephus tells of the Temple mount. Comp. also Targum Is. 28.21,
as well as the references given at the end of the preceding note; add ARN 9, 42. On leprosy as a punishment for arrogance see ARN, loc. cit., and vol. III, p. 214. According to Tan. Noah 13,
the passion with which Uzziah devoted himself to the cultivation of the soil (comp. 2 Chron. 26.10) caused him to neglect the study of the Torah. The evil consequence thereof was that
he became arrogant, saying: "God is king, and so am I, and it behooves the terrestrial king to do the service in the Temple of the celestial king." As the "love of husbandry" caused the
downfall of Uzziah, even so was it the cause of that of Cain and Noah. Comp. also Yelammedenu, No. 43 (here Cain, Job, and Uzziah are given); BR 22.3; Mekilta RS, 92 (where Cain, Noah, Lot,
and Uzziah are described as the four men who were "greedy for husbandry", and came thereby to grief).—The statement of Josephus that a ray of sunlight caused Uzziah's leprosy is evidently
based on a haggadic interpretation of (זרחה) +(והצרעת) in 2 Chron. 26.19, the usual meaning of זרח being "shone" in regard to the sun. See, however, also vol. Ill, p. 303, and note 197 on vol. III,
p. 90 (bottom) in connection with death by celestial fire as a punishment for the laity usurping the priesthood.<br><br>
31 Tan. Zaw 13; comp. vol. III, p. 303. As to the earthquake taking place on the day on which Uzziah attempted his sacrifice, see references cited in the two preceding notes; and Jerome on Amos 1,3.<br><br>



</p>
</div>
</div>


</p>
</div>
</div>

<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>

</p>

<li>from <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0006ginz_b8e2/page/358/mode/2up">archive.org</a></li>
</ul>




<iframe src="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0006ginz_b8e2/page/358/mode/2up?#"

<h7>Chronology</h7>

<table class="wrappingarcheotable">

<tr>
<th>Date</th>
<th>Reference</th>
<th>Corrections</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>750/751 BCE<br>(Thiele's chronology)</td>
<td>Like Josephus and Avot de Rabbi Nathan (Traditional Version A), <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">Ginzberg (1936:262)</a>
synchronizes the earthquake with the day that <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a>
attempted to offer sacrifices at the 1st Temple in Jerusalem and, in the process, contracted leprosy and experienced an earthquake which damaged the Temple.</td>
<td>none</td>
<td>
<ul>
<li>The earthquake is synchronized with the day <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a>
contracted leprosy.</li>
<li><q>Thiele dates <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> being struck with leprosy to 751/750 BCE,
at which time his son <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jotham">Jotham</a> took over the government</q>
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">wikipedia</a>)</li>
<li><a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt09b15.htm#5">2 Kings 15:5</a> and
<a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt25b26.htm#19">2 Chronicles 26:19-21</a> discuss how
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzziah">King Uzziah</a> was struck with leprosy but do not synchronize this with an earthquake.
<a href="https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt25b26.htm#19">2 Chronicles 26:19-20</a> (written later than 2 Kings and using 2 Kings as some of its source material)
does, however, synchronize Uzziah's unlawful actions at the Temple with the recognition of leprosy on the face of the King.</li>
<li>As evidenced by his footnotes, <a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">Ginzberg (1936:262)</a>'s sources are a complicated mix of
Rabbinic and other sources and include Josephus and Avot de Rabbi Nathan (Traditional Version A). His "seismic" source may not be independent (at least fully independent) from
Josephus as stated by <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">
Austin et al (2000:663)</a>. The text by Ginzberg describing seismic effects are essentially identical to Josephus' account. Thus, in all likelihood, the
"seismic source" here is Josephus [or Jospehus' source(s)] and <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">
Austin et al (2000:663)</a> overstated that <q>details of the earthquake and landslide, as described by Josephus, are independently supported by very old
traditions of the rabbis (Ginzberg, 1936, p. 262)</q></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>

</table>

<h7>Seismic Effects</h7>

<ul>
<li><q>the earth quaked so violently that a great breach was torn in the Temple</q></li>
<li><q>On the west side of Jerusalem, half of the mountain was split off and hurled to the east, into a road, at a distance of four stadia [0.75 km.].</q></li>
<li>statements above are almost identical to statements by Josephus</li>
</ul>

<h7>Locations</h7>

<ul>
<li>First Temple in Jerusalem</li>
</ul>

Austin, S. A., et al. (2000). "Amos's Earthquake: An Extraordinary Middle East Seismic Event of 750 B.C."
International Geology Review 42(7): 657-671.</a><br><br>

<a href="http://www.icr.org/article/scientific-scriptural-impact-amos-earthquake/">
Austin, S. 2010. The Scientific and Scriptural Impact of Amos' Earthquake. Acts & Facts. 39 (2): 8-9.</a><br><br>

<a href="https://archive.org/details/legendsofjews0004ginz/page/262/mode/2up">
Ginzberg, L. (1936). "Legends of the Jews." Philadelphia, Jewish Publ. Soc. Amer. vol. 4</a><br><br>

<div style="padding:10px;">

<h3 id="startA">Archaeoseismic Evidence</h3>
<table id="Archaeo" class="wrappingarcheotable" style="width:100%; white-space:normal;">

<thead>
<tr>
<th>Location (with hotlink)</th>
<th>Status</th>
<th>Intensity</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><a href="#JerusalemIntro">Jerusalem - Introduction</a></td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#JerusalemCityOfDavid">Jerusalem - City of David</a></td>
<td>possible to probable</td>
<td>≥ 8</td>
<td><a href="https://www.academia.edu/51723488/Archaeological_Evidence_of_an_Earthquake_in_the_Capital_of_Judah">Uziel and Chalaf (2021:55*)</a> discovered
an 8th century BCE destruction layer in the earliest layer of Building 17081 in Area U where they found fallen stones above <q>a row of smashed vessels ...
along its northern wall</q>. The fallen stones appeared to be from <q>the upper part of the walls of the room, which had collapsed</q>. They attributed
the collapse to an earthquake. Dating was based on ceramics with one of the smashed vessels identified as Iron Age IIB - i.e. 8th century BCE.
<a href="https://www.academia.edu/51723488/Archaeological_Evidence_of_an_Earthquake_in_the_Capital_of_Judah">Uziel and Chalaf (2021:60*-61*)</a>
also re-interpreted destruction evidence at Area E, just south of Area U, in the City of David where they suggested that Stratum 12B contained a collapse
layer likely caused by the same 8th century BCE seismic event seen in Area U.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#EnHaseva">En Hazeva</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>≥ 6</td>
<td><a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/3210498">Cohen and Yisrael (1995)</a> suggested that the Iron Age II "Middle Fortress" was most likely damaged by a mid 8th century BCE earthquake
mentioned in the Book of Amos (<a href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos%201&version=NIV">1:1</a>). The fortress, dated from ceramics to the 8th-9th centuries BCE,
suffered final destruction via either human agency or an earthquake. <a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/3210498">Cohen and Yisrael (1995)</a> dated earthquake damage to ca. 760 BCE relying on
<abbr Title="Primarily Biblical">historical texts</abbr> and comparison to archaeoseismic damage at
<abbr Title="Stratum VI at Hazor, Stratum IV at Lachish and Gezer, and, speculatively Phase IX at Deir' Alla and Stratum III at Beer-sheva">other sites</abbr> rather than
precise archaeological dating from En Haseva and they dated it's final destruction by human agency to ~735 BCE - also based on <abbr Title="Primarily Biblical">historical texts</abbr>.
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298846141_Amos%27s_earthquake_An_extraordinary_Middle_East_seismic_event_of_750_BC">Austin et al (2000)</a> (and apparently others)
have suggested that the tilted gate wall

<div class="gallery" style = "display: inline-block;" >
<div class="tooltip" style = "display: inline-block;">
<img src="http://www.deadseaquake.info/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/TH000046_DigTheod_TiltedIronAgeWallAtEnHaseva-scaled.jpg" alt="">
<img src="http://www.deadseaquake.info/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/TH000046_DigTheod_TiltedIronAgeWallAtEnHaseva-scaled.jpg" width="2800%" alt="">
<span class="tooltiptext">Digital Theodolite Shot of Tilted Iron Age Gate Wall at En Hatseva<br><br>Photo by Jefferson Williams 12 Jan. 2023</span>
</div>
</div>

of En Hatseva was tilted by the Amos Quake although a question remains why the other walls were not tilted.
<a href="https://escholarship.org/uc/item/9rv3v8tc">Roberts (2012:187-189)</a> notes that floors were
absent in the casemate walls which suggests an alternative theory for the wall tilt - poor construction
led to differential subsidence.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Samaria">Samaria-Sebaste</a></td>
<td>no evidence</td>
<td></td>
<td>needs investigation. There is no archaeoseismic evidence at this site for an 8th century BCE earthquake that I am aware of.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Schechem">Shechem</a></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>


<tr>
<td><a href="#IraqElAmir">Iraq el-Amir</a></td>
<td>no evidence</td>
<td></td>
<td>needs investigation. There is no archaeoseismic evidence at this site for an 8th century BCE earthquake that I am aware of.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Hazor">Hazor</a></td>
<td>possible to probable</td>
<td>7</td>
<td>Stratum VI Earthquake - Excavations by Yigal Yadin at Hazor in the last half of the 1950s uncovered fairly compelling archaeoseismic
evidence on the south side of Area A in Stratum VI
(see, for example, <a href="https://archive.org/details/hazoriiaccountof0000jame/page/n7/mode/2up">Yadin et. al., 1959</a>,
<a href="https://archive.org/details/hazoriiiivaccoun0000jame_d6c8">Yadin et. al., 1960</a>,
<a href="https://archive.org/details/hazorwithchapter0000yadi">Yadin, 1970</a>, and/or
<a href="https://archive.org/details/hazorrediscovery00yadi">Yadin, 1975</a>). The excavators encountered
tilted and collapsed walls including collapses which preserved the original courses, inclined pillars, and
fallen ceilings with extensive debris from ceiling plaster lying on floors.
Broken jars were found on the floors and some expensive luxury items were found in the debris. Stratum VI is fairly well dated. Pottery
dates it to the 8th century BCE perhaps even the first half of that century (<a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/23623620">Dever, 1992:28*</a>
and <a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/1357451">Finkelstein, 1999:65 Table 1</a>).
The overlying Stratum, Stratum V, is terminated by a burned destruction layer which appears to coincide with the
Assyrian destruction of Hazor in 732 BCE. Thus, it appears that Stratum VI contains a seismic destruction layer from the first half of the
8th century BCE which may coincide with one of the Amos Quakes. Renewed excavations in 1990s under the direction of Amnon Ben-Tor
uncovered more archaeoseismic evidence in Stratum VI <q>especially in a street and drain in Area A that seemed simply to have split
down the centre — difficult to explain by any other hypothesis</q>
(<a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/23623620">Dever, 1992:28* relying on personal communication with Amnon Ben-Tor</a>).<br><br>

A number of walls were described as tilting to the south and to the east.
<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">
Ben-Menahem (1991)</a> took this as evidence that Hazor was in the near field of seismic energy when the earthquake struck
and estimated that the epicenter was only ~20 km. to the northeast.

<blockquote>
According to the report of the excavating archeologists
[<a href="https://archive.org/details/hazoriiaccountof0000jame/page/n7/mode/2up">Yadin et. al., 1959</a>], northern walls were tilted
southward, while western walls tilted eastward. Figure
8 shows that these orientations are consistent with the
effect of a near field horizontal shear acceleration coming
to Hazor from the north east. This is consistent
with modern ideas that structures in the near-field of a
major earthquake are mostly affected by SH body waves
and the fundamental Love mode.
(<a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">
Ben-Menahem, 1991</a>)
</blockquote>

While this may be correct, a true archaeoseismic survey was not conducted on the site in order to,
for example, make exact measurements of tilting directions and inclinations, look for shifted ashlars, see if
there were rotated stones, etc..
The fact that the damage was concentrated on the south side of Area A rather than throughout the entire site
casts doubt on <a href="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/CollectionOfEarthquakeCatalogs/BenMenahem1991.html">
Ben-Menahem (1991)</a>'s estimate of a M<sub>L</sub> = 7.3 earthquake with an epicenter a mere ~20 km. to the NE
of the site. An earthquake that large and that close would have probably caused extensive damage throughout the site; not just
on the south side of Area A. In addition, as noted by
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/226318671_Seismogenic_Origin_of_the_Ancient_Avdat_Ruins_Negev_Desert_Israel">
Korzhenkov and Mazor (1999)</a>, <q>areas above a hypo-center do not reveal systematic inclination and collapse patterns,
whereas some distance away inclination and collapse have pronounced directional patterns</q>. Thus, while the archaeoseismic evidence
does suggest that an earthquake struck the site, shaking would have been moderate rather than severe.
<b>This site may be subject to a ridge effect</b>.
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Megiddo">Megiddo</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>≥ 8</td>
<td>Stratum IVA Earthquake (after ca. 800 BCE) - A destruction layer was found in Level H-5 of Area H which correlates to Stratum VA-IVB.
<a href="https://www.google.co.il/books/edition/Megiddo_V/_V3anQEACAAJ?hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjEgI3Iq7b-AhVORvEDHWXeCFcQiKUDegQIERAE">
Eran Arie in Finkelstein et al. (2013 Vol. 1:270-272)</a> reported evidence of collapse and destruction by fire while
<a href="https://archive.org/details/knauf-e.-a.-2002-excavating-biblical-history-revelations-from-meggido-the-newsle/page/n1/mode/2up">
Knauf (2002:2)</a> reports that <q>the occupation of Phase H5a [which correlates to Stratum IVA] was
terminated by an earthquake, which cracked the city wall and strewed parts of walls
of these southern buildings all over Area H.</q><br><br>
<a href="https://www.academia.edu/34027017/Megiddo_Earthquakes_Megiddo_IV_Chapter_31_">Marco et. al. (2006)</a>
observed that a staircase between the Iron II gate complex and a reservoir was tilted and faulted, a wall in the courtyard of the
Southern Stables tilted to the west, there were fractures in the walls of a Silo (1404), and there were fractures in the limestone bedrock
of Tunnel 1000 of the water system. Although they suggested the most likely candidate for this archaeoseismic evidence was the
~760 BCE Amos Quake, they noted that an inability to establish a terminus ante quem created chronological uncertainty and opened up the possibility
that the causitive earthquake struck later. The terminus post quem was c. 800 BCE. In addition, none of their observed archaeoseismic evidence
is particularly compelling.
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Gezer">Gezer</a></td>
<td>possible to probable</td>
<td>≥ 8</td>
<td> 8th century BCE Earthquake - In the vicinity of what <a href="https://archive.org/details/in.gov.ignca.33822/page/250/mode/2up">Macalister (1912 vol.1:251)</a>
labeled as "Tower VI" and "Tower VII", the outer city wall was variously displaced, tilted, or folded. At "Tower VI", joints traversing
adjacent ashlars and shifted ashlars were observed. Dating appears to have been assisted by a terminus ante quem due to a destruction
layer created when the Assyrians seiged the city in 733 BCE. <a href="https://www.academia.edu/1919233/A_Preliminary_Report_of_the_1990_Season_at_Tel_Gezer">
Younker (1991)</a> reports that debris layers consisting of <q>fallen ashlar blocks in a bricky fill containing 8th century BCE sherds
were found above 10th century BCE fill from an excavation against the outer face of Macalister's "Tower VII"</q>. This would
seem to date the apparent outer wall archaeoseismic evidence to the 8th century BCE and before 733 BCE.
<b>This site may be subject to a ridge effect</b>.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#TelAteret">Tel Ateret aka Vadun Jacob</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td></td>
<td>Iron Age IIA and later Earthquake(s) - 980 BCE - 142 BCE - <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283893583_Archaeological_record_of_earthquake_ruptures_in_Tell_Ateret_the_Dead_Sea_Fault">Ellenblum et. al. (2015:6)</a>
uncovered Iron Age IIA remains (ca. 980-830 BCE) to the south and partially beneath the Hellenistic ruins in the southern part of the site. Preliminary dating was based on
architectural style and pottery typologies.
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283893583_Archaeological_record_of_earthquake_ruptures_in_Tell_Ateret_the_Dead_Sea_Fault">Ellenblum et. al. (2015:6)</a> estimated
that the Iron Age IIA wall was displaced 8 m across the fault with 6 m of displacement taking place after the early Hellenistic period. This left 2 m of displacement in an
<q>unknown number of events during the first millennium BCE prior to the 142 BCE earthquake</q>.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#FortArad">Arad</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>≥ 8</td>
<td>Stratum XI Earthquake - 2nd half of the 9th century BCE to the 1st half of the 8th century BCE -
<a href="https://www.academia.edu/23190918/The_Fortress_Mound_at_Tel_Arad_an_Interim_Report">
Herzog (2002:96-97)</a> suggested that the ~760 BCE Amos Quake
destroyed fortifications at Arad in Stratum XI leading to the rebuilding observed in Stratum X.
Since his earthquake assignment was based on rebuilding evidence, no seismic effects
were observed but one could assume that, if <a href="https://www.academia.edu/23190918/The_Fortress_Mound_at_Tel_Arad_an_Interim_Report">
Herzog (2002)</a>'s seismic interpretation is correct, that there would have been some collapsed walls
in Stratum XI. <a href="https://www.academia.edu/23190918/The_Fortress_Mound_at_Tel_Arad_an_Interim_Report">
Herzog (2002:94)</a> dated Stratum XI to between the second half of the 9th century BCE and the first half of the 8th century BCE.
He used the 'low chronology' of Finkelstein and dating was based on pottery, comparison with other sites, climate change, interpretation
of socio-political developments, and architectural style.
It appears that the ~760 BCE Amos Quake was used to assign the end date of Stratum XI and
an association with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shishak">Pharaoh Shishak</a>'s raid in 926 BCE and other
concomitant phenomenon was used to assign the start date. Arad was mentioned in the list of cities conquered by
Pharaoh Shishak in 926 BCE (<a href="https://www.academia.edu/23190918/The_Fortress_Mound_at_Tel_Arad_an_Interim_Report">
Herzog, 2002:92</a>). <a href="https://www.academia.edu/2004969/Arad_the_Iron_Age_pottery_assemblages">
Singer-Avitz (2002:162)</a> noted that there was <q>no clear indication of the date of the establishment of Stratum X</q>
which followed Stratum XI. This inferred archaeoseismic evidence is not particularly well dated.
The Intensity estimate is based on an assumption of collapsed walls.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Lachish">Lachish</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>6-8 (possibly greater than 8)</td>
<td>Level IV Earthquake (?) - ~8th century BCE (?) - <a href="https://www.academia.edu/96114764/Biblical_Lachish_A_Tale_of_Construction_Destruction_Excavation_and_Restoration_in_English_PDF_of_the_complete_book_">
Ussishkin (2014:214)</a> wrote that <q>it is not at all clear why the fortified city of Lachish Level IV came to an
end and Level III was built.</q> <a href="https://www.academia.edu/96114764/Biblical_Lachish_A_Tale_of_Construction_Destruction_Excavation_and_Restoration_in_English_PDF_of_the_complete_book_">
Ussishkin (2014:214)</a> noted changes to the the City Gate, building and rebuilding activity in domestic structures in Area S,
and changes to the superstructures but not the foundations of the Palace Fort and the
Southern Annex. The <q>city walls seem to have continued in use unchanged.</q> Level III structures were said to resemble their Level IV
predecessors. Numerous broken pottery vessels found in Level IV of Area S (domestic dwellings) was thought to <q>allude to sudden destruction</q>
but <q>nothing was found that would indicate that this destruction had been intentional or that an enemy had set fire to it.</q> Moshe Kochavi, who
had excavated with Yigal Yadin at Hazor in 1955 (<a href="https://escholarship.org/uc/item/9rv3v8tc">Roberts, 2012</a>), was said to have
visited Lachish in 1976 and suggested that Level IV was destroyed by the Amos Quake
(<a href="https://www.academia.edu/96114764/Biblical_Lachish_A_Tale_of_Construction_Destruction_Excavation_and_Restoration_in_English_PDF_of_the_complete_book_">
Ussishkin, 2014:215</a>).
While Excavator David Ussishkin has reported this as a possibility, he has never mentioned it as a certainty or even a probability in a number of
subsequent publications about Lachish. In addition to the mystery of what led to the destruction of Level IV, there is a chronological debate
over it's date that largely stems from a lack of sufficient evidence to date it solely from material found at the site.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Gath">Tell es-Safi (Gath)</a></td>
<td>probable</td>
<td><abbr Title="Based on a PGA estimate of 1g for the sheared wall in Area F which equates to an Intensity of IX (9)">9</abbr></td>
<td>Stratum F8A Earthquake - early to mid 8th century BCE - <a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5615/neareastarch.81.1.0048">
Chadwick and Maeir (2018)</a> uncovered collapsed walls of what was
a then abandoned domestic dwelling in Area F. Brick collapses were
all found to be sloping northward <q>having shifted violently and
simultaneously north off their stone foundations.</q> They added that
<q>in some cases the lower courses of brick wall superstructures were
still intact, and in one instance the flat course lines
of a wall showed where its second course had sheared cleanly away from
its foundation course, lying slanted over a meter north of its original line.</q>
They report that <q>consulting engineers Oded Rabinovitch (The Technion, Israel Institute of
Technology) and Amos Shiran estimated it would have taken 1 g-force of
energy to move the walls off their foundations in this manner.</q> This equates
to a local Intensity of ~IX using the equation of
<a href="https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1193/1.1586058">Wald et. al. (1999)</a>.<br><br>

A bit below the collapse layer was Stratum F9 - dated as Iron IIA and interpreted as reflecting Philistine occupation.
Above this layer <q>two successive debris layers were found: a layer of destruction debris from the attack of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazael">Hazael (r. 842-796 BCE)</a>'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aram-Damascus">Aramean</a>
forces, and atop that another layer of eroded brick detritus, winter rain-wash,
and wind-blown soils</q> which had <q>all accumulated as the abandoned houses decayed over several decades.</q>
Collapse Layer F8A was found above this detritus and was overlain by a <q>much thinner layer of winter rain-wash and wind-blown soil</q>
which in turn was covered by Judahite structures dated by ceramics to the 8th century BCE and which were probably built
<q>as early as the mid-eighth century B.C.E.</q> and
were designated as Stratum 8 which <q>was discerned across the entire area.</q> Because the Judahites buried
the F8A <q>earthquake collapses under new terraces and fills in Area F</q>, the chronology of seismic destruction
was preserved enabling the excavators to supply a confident date of the early to middle part of the 8th century BCE
for this seismic shaking in Stratum F8A.<br><br>


In addition to the collapsed wall in Area F, <a href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5615/neareastarch.81.1.0048">
Chadwick and Maeir (2018)</a> report that <q>walls collapsed by the earthquake</q> were also found in
<q>in Area A, on the flatter terrain of Gath's lower east side, and in Area D of the northern lower city.</q> </td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Judeideh">Tell ej-Judeideh</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>≥ 8</td>
<td>Lower Phase of Iron IIB Earthquake (?) - 8th century BCE -
<a href="https://www.academia.edu/70232588/The_Tell_ej_Judeideh_Tel_Goded_Excavations_A_Re_Appraisal_Based_on_Archival_Records_in_the_Palestine_Exploration_Fund">
Gibson (1994)</a> re-appraised earlier excavations reported in
<a href="https://zenodo.org/record/2130558/files/article.pdf">
Bliss (1900a)</a>, <a href="https://ia600708.us.archive.org/view_archive.php?archive=/22/items/crossref-pre-1909-scholarly-works/10.1179%252Fpeq.1899.31.3.200.zip&file=10.1179%252Fpeq.1900.32.3.199.pdf">
Bliss (1900b)</a>, and <a href="https://archive.org/details/excavationsinpal00blis/page/44/mode/2up">
Bliss and Macalister (1902)</a>. He detected two Iron IIB level building phases noting that
<q>the structures from the lower phase were apparently destroyed (in an earthquake?) and then, in the upper
phase, [] rebuilt roughly along the same lines.</q> The pottery <q>belonging to the lower
phase did not contain the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LMLK_seal">lmlk stamped handles</a>
so typical of the upper phase
(<a href="https://ia600708.us.archive.org/view_archive.php?archive=/22/items/crossref-pre-1909-scholarly-works/10.1179%252Fpeq.1899.31.3.200.zip&file=10.1179%252Fpeq.1900.32.3.199.pdf">Bliss
1900b:219</a>)</q> which led <a href="https://www.academia.edu/70232588/The_Tell_ej_Judeideh_Tel_Goded_Excavations_A_Re_Appraisal_Based_on_Archival_Records_in_the_Palestine_Exploration_Fund">
Gibson (1994)</a> to conclude that <q>the lower phase of the Iron IIB level at Judeideh may be the
equivalent of Level IV at Lachish.</q> <a href="https://www.academia.edu/96114764/Biblical_Lachish_A_Tale_of_Construction_Destructione_Excavation_and_Restoration_in_English_PDF_of_the_complete_book_">
Ussishkin (2014:214)</a> mentioned the possibility that Lachish Level IV ended in destruction by the Amos Quake.
According to <a href="https://www.academia.edu/70232588/The_Tell_ej_Judeideh_Tel_Goded_Excavations_A_Re_Appraisal_Based_on_Archival_Records_in_the_Palestine_Exploration_Fund">
Gibson (1994)</a>, the destroyed structures at Tell ej-Judeideh were reported in
Pit 4 by Maclister where <q>an earlier system of walls</q> were <q>detected beneath the structures of the upper Iron IIB phase.</q>
<a href="https://www.academia.edu/70232588/The_Tell_ej_Judeideh_Tel_Goded_Excavations_A_Re_Appraisal_Based_on_Archival_Records_in_the_Palestine_Exploration_Fund">
Gibson (1994)</a> also noted that <q>Macalister pointed out that many of the stones from the lower phase walls had been re-used in the upper phase walls.</q><br><br>

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LMLK_seal">lmlk stamped handles</a> are thought to have have first
been issued around 700 BCE during the reign of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hezekiah">King Hezekiah</a>
(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LMLK_seal">wikipedia</a>). <a href="https://www.academia.edu/70232588/The_Tell_ej_Judeideh_Tel_Goded_Excavations_A_Re_Appraisal_Based_on_Archival_Records_in_the_Palestine_Exploration_Fund">
Gibson (1994)</a> suggested that the upper phase of Iron IIB at Tell ej-Judeideh which contained <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LMLK_seal">lmlk stamped handles</a>
ended in destruction by
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sennacherib">Sennacherib</a> in 701 BCE and was equivalent to Lachish Level III.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#TelAgol">Tel Agol</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>≥ 8</td>
<td>Stratum IIIB Earthquake - probably in the mid-eighth century BCE -
<a href="http://hadashot-esi.org.il/report_detail_eng.aspx?id=26054&mag_id=133">Feig (2021a)</a> reports damage to casemate walls in
Stratum IIIB which she interpreted to be due to seismic shaking. She estimated the date of the damaging event to
<q>probably in the mid-eighth century BCE.</q> Underlying Stratum IV was dated, based on pottery, to Iron Age II -
<q>probably Iron IIA</q>. Overlying Stratum II showed evidence of repairs to the Stratum IIIB walls. As there were
no signs of <q>destruction or devastation</q> due to the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiglath-Pileser_III#Conquest_of_the_Levant">Assyrian conquest in 732 BCE</a>,
the excavator surmised that the settlement may have been abandoned around that time.
Observed damage included collapsed, displaced, and folded walls along with broken pottery found in fallen position.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#DeirAlla">Deir 'Alla</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>≥7</td>
<td>Phase M/IX Earthquakes - 8th or 9th century BCE -
Extensive archaeoseismic evidence was uncovered at Deir 'Alla in Phase M (aka Phase IX), particularly in Area B.
The mud brick walls of the damaged structures <q>were built on top of existing surfaces,
and occasionally on reed layers or wooden beams</q>
(<a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Aramaic_Texts_from_Deir_%CA%BBAlla/fpo3AAAAIAAJ?hl=en">Franken, 1976</a>).
They lacked a true foundation and the walls were only one mudbrick thick
(<a href="http://publication.doa.gov.jo/Publications/ViewChapterPublic/2173">Ibrahim and van der Kooij, 1986:135-142</a>).
They were not seismically resistant. Some of the archaeoseismic evidence looks like
what one would see in a paleoseismic trench with some vertical mostly E-W cracks extending through the top of the
stratigraphic layer (M/IX) and ending where other deposits began. One crack was described as being 10 cm. wide and extensional
(<a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Aramaic_Texts_from_Deir_%CA%BBAlla/fpo3AAAAIAAJ?hl=en">Franken, 1976</a>).
Some of the mudbrick walls broke away at floor level while others broke above the floor
<q>but after the whole wall had shifted</q>
(<a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Aramaic_Texts_from_Deir_%CA%BBAlla/fpo3AAAAIAAJ?hl=en">Franken, 1976</a>).
<q>Complete pottery, though often broken by the destruction of the buildings, was found in almost all of the rooms</q>
of Area B (<a href="http://publication.doa.gov.jo/Publications/ViewChapterPublic/2173">Ibrahim and van der Kooij, 1986:138</a>).<br><br>

The stratigraphically confined cracks were caused by the second earthquake as this location recorded two earthquakes in the 8th century BCE
(<a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Aramaic_Texts_from_Deir_%CA%BBAlla/fpo3AAAAIAAJ?hl=en">Franken, 1976</a>).
The first earthquake led to a fire and, apparently, some
type of abandonment (<a href="https://archive.org/details/the-balaam-text-from-deir-alla-re-evaluated/page/16/mode/2up">
Ibrahim and van der Kooij, 1991</a>). The second earthquake occurred
<q>after some time, because the new surface had been used a bit</q>
(<a href="https://archive.org/details/the-balaam-text-from-deir-alla-re-evaluated/page/16/mode/2up">
Ibrahim and van der Kooij, 1991</a>).
<a href="http://publication.doa.gov.jo/Publications/ViewChapterPublic/2268">
Franken and Ibrahim (1978:60-68)</a> suggested that it was raining when
the second earthquake struck. Dating from radiocarbon, pottery
(not wheel thrown), palaeography
of an inscription found in the rubble left by the second earthquake, and
cultural relations (i.e. before Assyrian influence
was visible) suggest an 8th or 9th century BCE date.<br><br>

<b>This site in Phase M (IX) appears to have been subject to a construction related site effect</b> due to the
foundation-less one mudbrick thick buildings built on top of what <a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Aramaic_Texts_from_Deir_%CA%BBAlla/fpo3AAAAIAAJ?hl=en">
Franken (1976:9)</a> described as clay.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
<tfoot>

<th>Status</th>
<th>Intensity</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
</tfoot>
</table>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Tell Saidiyeh</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


ck Ferry's references


</p>
</div>
</div>


<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Tel Qasile</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<b>Tel Qasile</b><br><br>

Ambraseys (2009)<br><br>

<p><b>1100-1050 BC - Ambraseys (2009)</b></p>

<p> For Tell Qasile, which is included in the list of
sites damaged by the earthquake of 760 BC, <b>archaeological
evidence suggests that the site was damaged during
the period 1100-1050 BC (Dothan and Dunayevsky 1993;
Mazar 1993, 298; Stern 1993).</b></p>

[15] Tell Qasile<br>
Estimated period of occurrence: Stratum XI of Tel Qasile
belongs to the phase Iron Age IB (= first half of the
eleventh century BC).<br>

<p>Extract of pertinent statement by author relating to earthquake
damage:</p>

<p><em>`Stratum XI was completely cleared in the southern
part of the mound, where a large building, built mostly of
kurkar stones, was found. The structure's plan was not fully
traced. East of it was a large square, and nearby were two
clay crucibles containing remains of smelted copper. In the
northern sector of the mound, the buildings in this stratum
were destroyed down to their foundations when the stratum
X buildings were erected. The nature of the ruins indicates
that the settlement was destroyed by an earthquake.
The fortifications in Area B include a massive brick
wall (c. 5 m thick) in stratum XI. No architectural continuity
was noted between strata XII and XI. The latter was laid
out on a different plan and a new wall was added.
It was possible to distinguish clearly between the
different Iron Age I strata (XIIâX) at Tell Qasile; thus, separate
and well-defined pottery assemblages could be established.
Changes and developments can be traced in the ordinary
local pottery, in which the Canaanite pottery tradition
continues, as well as in the Philistine ware. The stratum XII
Philistine pottery includes bowls, kraters, jugs with strainer
spouts, and stirrup jars. The pottery contains several distinctive
features that date it tb the early phase of its appearance
in Israel: thick white slip and bichrome decoration on
some of the vessels with narrow, close-set lines, similar to
the Mycenaean "close style"; the bird motif is limited to
stratum XII (only one example was found in stratum XI).
The ceramic assemblage of stratum XI is similar to that
of stratum XII. However, a change is discernible in the
Philistine pottery: there is a deterioration in ornamentation,
and monochrome decorations become more frequent.
Other finds in this stratum include bronze arrowheads, a
bone graver, spindle whorls, flint sickle blades, numerous
loom weights, and various stone objects, such as grindstones
and mortars. Iron objects were not found in Area A in strata
XII and XI'</em> (Dothan and Dunayevsky 1993).</p>


<b>Location Info</b>


<p><a href="http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343200210">http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343200210</a></p>


<p><b>References</b></p>

Ambraseys, N. (2009). Earthquakes in the Mediterranean and Middle East: a multidisciplinary study of seismicity up to 1900. Cambridge, UK, Cambridge University Press.<br><br>
<a href="http://books.google.com/books/about/Earthquakes_in_the_Mediterranean_and_Mid.html?id=x2veAAAACAAJ">http://books.google.com/books/about/Earthquakes_in_the_Mediterranean_and_Mid.html?id=x2veAAAACAAJ</a><br><br>





</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Be'er Sheva'</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>



<b>Be'er Sheva'</b><br><br>

Approximate Location - Austin et. al. (2000), Ambraseys (2009)<br><br>


<p><b>759 BC - Austin et. al. (2000) </b></p>

<p>Tel Sheva, identified by some as biblical Beersheva,
<b>shows signs of earthquake destruction in the
Stratum III. This destruction was dated by the excavator
to the middle of the eighth century B.C. (Aharoni,
1973, p. 107)</b>.</p>


<p><b>759 BC - Ambraseys (2009)</b></p>

<p>[9] Tel Beersheba (Tel Sheva)<br>
Estimated period of occurrence: 760 BC.<br></p>

<p>Extract of pertinent statement by author relating to earthquake
damage:</p>

<p>. . and Beersheva depends largely upon the opinion
of Aharoni, thus far unsupported by an adequate publication,
see Y. Aharoni et al., Beer-Sheba I. Excavations at
Tell Beer-Sheba, 1969-1971 Seasons (Tel Aviv 1973) 107.'
(Dever 1992, 35* n. 10).</p>

<p><em>`At Tel Beersheba, Strata V and IV cover the period
equivalent to that of Stratum XI at Tel Arad. The plan of
Stratum III at Tel Beersheba is, again, drastically different
from that of Stratum IV. The former solid city wall
and city gate were completely razed, and a new fortification
system was constructed. We subscribe to the "low chronology",
these changes may not be attributed to Shishak's
raid or to the division of the alleged United Monarchy. If
so, what generated such a cultural shift? Since typological
modification runs parallel to drastic changes in the design
of settlements, as observed at Tel Beersheba and Lachish,
they should be related to significant events. <b>Tentatively this
development might be associated with a severe earthquake
dated to c. 760 BCE, based on biblical references (Dever
1992). A strong earthquake in the southern part of the
Judean Kingdom might explain the total destruction of the
upper parts of the fortification systems at Tel Arad XI and
Beersheba IV and the need to rebuild them in Strata X and
III, respectively' </em>(Herzog 2002, 97-98).</b></p>


<p><b>Location Info</b></p>

<p><a href="http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343100771">http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343100771</a></p>

<p><a href="http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343200103">http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343200103</a></p>



<p><b>References</b></p>

Ambraseys, N. (2009). Earthquakes in the Mediterranean and Middle East: a multidisciplinary study of seismicity up to 1900. Cambridge, UK, Cambridge University Press.<br><br>
<a href="http://books.google.com/books/about/Earthquakes_in_the_Mediterranean_and_Mid.html?id=x2veAAAACAAJ">http://books.google.com/books/about/Earthquakes_in_the_Mediterranean_and_Mid.html?id=x2veAAAACAAJ</a><br><br>

<p>Austin, S. A., et al. (2000). "Amos's Earthquake: An Extraordinary Middle East Seismic Event of 750 B.C."
International Geology Review 42(7): 657-671.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00206810009465104#">http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00206810009465104#</a></p>


<p>Yadin, Y. and S. Angress (1960). Hazor II: an account of the second season of excavations, 1956, Magnes Press, Hebrew University.</p>
<p><a href="http://books.google.com/books/about/Hazor_II.html?id=C-EMAQAAMAAJ">http://books.google.com/books/about/Hazor_II.html?id=C-EMAQAAMAAJ</a></p>

<div>Tel Abu Hawam</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>




<b>Tel Abu Hawam</b><br><br>

Approximate Location - Not 759 BC but 1125-1050 BC instead- Ambraseys (2009)<br><br><br><br>


<p><b>Not 759 BC but 1125-1050 BC instead - Ambraseys (2009)</b></p>

<p><b>Tell Abu Hawam was damaged between 1125-1050 BC (Balensi 1980, 586;Warren and Hankey 1989, 161).</b> </p>

<p>[23] Tell Abu Hawam</p>

damage:</p>

<p><em>`Stratum IVA (dates) from c. 1125 to c. 1050 B.C.
This city was violently destroyed, possibly by earthquake'</em>
(Warren and Hankey 1989, 161).</p>

<div>Tell Erany</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>



<b>Tell Erany</b><br><br>

Approximate Location - Austin et. al. (2000)<br><br>

<p><b>759 BC - Austin et. al. (2000)</b></p>

<p><b>Excavations at Tel Erany indicate a mid-eighth century
earthquake in Stratum VI of the acropolis
(Yeivin, 1979, p. 168). </b>Unfortunately, a final report
has not been published.</p>


<p><b>Location Info</b></p>

<p><a href="http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343100170">http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=343100170</a></p>

<p><b>References</b></p>

<p>Austin, S. A., et al. (2000). "Amos's Earthquake: An Extraordinary Middle East Seismic Event of 750 B.C."
International Geology Review 42(7): 657-671.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00206810009465104#">http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00206810009465104#</a></p>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Ain Ummal-Davaj possibly Bir Eyuh, En-Rogel</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


<b>Ain Ummal-Davaj possibly Bir Eyuh, En-Rogel</b><br><br>

759 BC ? - Ambraseys (2009)<br><br>

<p><a href="http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=353104901">
http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=353104901</a></p>

<p><b>759 BC ? - Ambraseys (2009)</b></p>

<p>Josephus in his Antiquities of the Jews
(AD 93), a book written about six centuries later, refers
to an earthquake that happened in the last months of
King Uzziah's life, which caused a crack in the Temple
at Jerusalem. Josephus adds that at a place called Enrogel,
outside the city, half of the mountain in the west
broke off from the rest and slid 800 m up to the mountain
on the east, spoiling the king's gardens [6]. Assuming
that the two authors refer to the same event, this passage
in Josephus seems to suggest that in all probability
Zechariah describes a landslide, perhaps triggered by
an earthquake, rather than a graben formed by normal
faulting.</p>

<p>There is a further reference to these events in
Uzziah's days by Nathan ha-Bavli, who was writing in the
middle of the second century AD. He does not mention
the earthquake, but he says that at the time of the desecration
of the temple by Uzziah the temple split open
and the fissure extended for twelve 'miles' in each direction
[6a].</p>

<p>The location of Azal is not certain, but the name
may denote some place near the western extremity of
the valley near Jerusalem or a hamlet on the outskirts of
Jerusalem. As for the location of En-rogel, it has been
suggested that it is the fountain of the Virgin, the modern
Ain Umm al-Daraj. Others identify it with Bir Eyub,
to the south of the Pool of Siloam, and below the junction
of the valleys of Kidron and Hinnom, which seems
to be a more probable location, but again this is not
certain.</p>






<br><br>



Fantalkin, A. and Finkelstein, I. 2006. The Sheshonq I Campaign and the 8th-Century
BCE Earthquake: More on the Archaeology and History of the South in the Iron I–
IIA. Tel Aviv 33:18–42.<br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Nahal Azal ? 759 BC Landslide ?</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>



<b>Nahal Azal ? 759 BC Landslide ? Ambraseys (2009)</b><br><br>



<p><b>Executive Summary</b></p>

<p>Some have interpreted a landslide description from the Biblical accounts regarding the Amos Quake. Ambraseys (2009) discusses this possibility below; suggesting a landslide probably did not occur,</p>

<p><b>759 BC ? - Ambraseys (2009)</b></p>

<p>About three centuries later, early in the sixth century
BC, Zechariah (c. 520 BC) mentions an earthquake
in Judaea, again in the days of King Uzziah and probably
the same event as that mentioned by Isaiah, which he says
affected Jerusalem and caused the Mount of Olives, east
of Jerusalem, to split and form a valley [3]. The interpretation
of this passage in Zechariah (14, 4-5), which seems
to be a later fifth- or fourth-century-BC insertion, is not
clear. Other versions of the same passage say that the
Mount of Olives will split in two and create a valley that
will reach Azel. This valley will run from east to west with
half of the Mount of Olives moving to the north, away
from the position it occupied, while the other half will
move to the south. The valley will stop where the mountains
will touch each other [3.1, 3-7].</p>

<p>A somewhat different reading is to be found in
the Masoretic version, where, following the mention of
the splitting of the Mount of Olives, it says that the valley
shall reach unto Azal, as compared with the Revised
Standard Version, which says instead that the valley shall
be stopped up, for the valley shall touch the side of it (the
mountain) [4, 5]. The source of this difference lies perhaps
in the confused reading of the Hebrew words for
`shall be stopped up' (ve-nistam), and 'you shall flee' (venastem).
The consonants are identical, but when the diacritical
points were added to the Hebrew Bible to facilitate
reading, the text was apparently misunderstood and
the meaning changed (see the editor's note in Wachs
and Lewitte 1984). Upon adopting the latter reading as
more plausible in relation to the natural phenomenon
described, it is obvious that there is no other explanation
than a large landslide, which may, or might not, have been
triggered by this or by another earthquake.
Also, Josephus in his Antiquities of the Jews
(AD 93), a book written about six centuries later, refers
to an earthquake that happened in the last months of
King Uzziah's life, which caused a crack in the Temple
at Jerusalem. Josephus adds that at a place called Enrogel,
outside the city, half of the mountain in the west
broke off from the rest and slid 800 m up to the mountain
on the east, spoiling the king's gardens [6]. Assuming
that the two authors refer to the same event, this passage
in Josephus seems to suggest that in all probability
Zechariah describes a landslide, perhaps triggered by
an earthquake, rather than a graben formed by normal
faulting.</p>

<p>There is a further reference to these events in
Uzziah's days by Nathan ha-Bavli, who was writing in the
middle of the second century AD. He does not mention
the earthquake, but he says that at the time of the desecration
of the temple by Uzziah the temple split open
and the fissure extended for twelve 'miles' in each direction
[6a].</p>

<p>The location of Azal is not certain, but the name
may denote some place near the western extremity of
the valley near Jerusalem or a hamlet on the outskirts of
Jerusalem. As for the location of En-rogel, it has been
suggested that it is the fountain of the Virgin, the modern
Ain Umm al-Daraj. Others identify it with Bir Eyub,
to the south of the Pool of Siloam, and below the junction
of the valleys of Kidron and Hinnom, which seems
to be a more probable location, but again this is not
certain.</p>

<p>There remains the question of whether there is
any evidence today for active faulting in the immediate
vicinity of Old Jerusalem that can be associated with the
ground deformations mentioned by Zechariah, Josephus
and Nathan. Old aerial photographs of the chalky geological
formations of the region show only landslides on
steep slopes, but no through-going faults. A relatively
large slide can be recognised on the Mount of Olives,
which is located on the slope which faces west towards the
Old City, the scarp of which can be seen halfway up the
Mount of Olives. However, according to the Geological
Survey of Israel, it is probably much more ancient than
Biblical times (Wachs and Lewitte 1984; Frydman 1997).
The multitude of short scarps shown on relatively recent
geological maps of Jerusalem all teiminate at the Kidron
Valley (Gil 1996). The exception is a short northeastsouthwest-
running fault trace, which is shown on the
Geotechnical Map of Jerusalem (Israeli 1977), which the
Atlas of Israel labels Zechariah 14:4, earthquake fault.
This feature extends from a point a few hundred metres
south of the Jerusalem Railway Station to the west, running
for more than three kilometres, to just north of al-
Ayzariyah to the east, striking about N-70Â° E (Atlas of
Israel1985). The reason why this feature has been associated
with Zechariah's earthquake is not given.
There is no direct or indirect evidence that
Jerusalem was damaged, and it is interesting that the
details in Josephus concerning the effects of the earthquake
on the temple are not supported by earlier sources,
which remain silent about damage anywhere in Judaea
and Israel [7].</p>

<p><b>Location Info</b></p>

<p><a href="http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=353105114">
http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=353105114</a></p>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Bethel</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>



<b>Bethel</b><br><br>

Approximate Location - Literary Evidence Only - Austin, S. A., et al. (2000)<br><br>


<b>Austin, S. A., et al. (2000)</b><br><br>

<b>At Bethel, Amos indicated severe damage to
altars, houses, and the temple (Amos 3:14,15; 9:1).
However, excavators have not located Bethel’s temple
at Beitin, and they provide only a general
description of damage (Kelso, 1968, p. 37, 52).</b> This
Iron Age II damage is neither precisely dated to
Jeroboam II’s time, nor has it been assigned to just
one earthquake.<br><br>

<b>Location Info</b><br><br>

<p><a href="http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=353102545">
http://daahl.ucsd.edu/DAAHL/SitesDataView.php?SiteNo=353102545</a></p>

<p><b>References</b></p>

<p>Austin, S. A., et al. (2000). "Amos's Earthquake: An Extraordinary Middle East Seismic Event of 750 B.C."
International Geology Review 42(7): 657-671.</p>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>Tel Rehov, Tel Dan, and Be'er Sheva</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


Per conversation with Steve Austin - 1/9/2020 - More archeoseismic evidence has been uncovered in Tel Rehov, Tel Dan, and Beersheva.
Also Elijah reports a drought in ~800 BC<br><br>




</p>

<div class="cPanel">

<div class="top expand">
<div>To Do</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanel">
<p>


See gearth for more textual references<br><br>



chase rafael and agnon refs in notes<br><br>

Uziel and Chalaf 2021 p 59 - Beyond the biblical text, paleo-seismic and archaeological data can be coupled to support the historicity
of an earthquake effecting the region in the mid-eighth century BCE. Destruction at sites in the north, such as Hazor (Yadin 1975),
Deir 'Alla (Agnon 2014), Gezer (Austin, Franz and Frost 2000), Tel Agol (Feig in press) and further south, Tell es-Safi/Gath
(Chadwick and Maeir 2018) have been attributed to the eighth century BCE earthquake. In fact, the effects of the earthquake had
affected both sides of the Jordan Valley Rift (Refael and Agnon 2018). <br><br>

dever 1992 - For these references, I am indebted to Mr. Gordon W. Franz for the use of his unpublished paper
`The Earthquake in the Days of King Uzziah: An Archaeological, Geological, and Theological Ap¬praisal
In the paper already cited (above, n. 2), Gordon Franz attempts to add several sites to Hazor VI and Lachish IV,
relating them to the 760 BCE earthquake, including `En Gev II, Deir `Alli phase IX ( = M), and Beersheva III.
°En Gev remains very speculative, and Beersheva depends largely
upon the opinion of Aharoni, thus far unsupported by an adequate publication; on the latter, see Y. Aharoni et al.,
Beer-Sheba I. Excavations at Tell Beer-Sheba, 1969-1971 Seasons, Tel Aviv 1973, p. 107. The empirical evidence at Deir
'Alla, dated to the mid-8th century BCE, perhaps by the famous "Balaam Inscription," is stronger; see M. Ibrahim &
G. van der Kooij, 'Excavations of Deir `Alla, Season 1979,' ADAJ 23 (1979), pp. 41-50. The case for Lachish IV is
perhaps the strongest; see D. Ussishkin, 'The Destruction of Lachish and the Dating of the Royal Judean Storage
Jars,' Tel Aviv 4/1-2 (1977), pp. 43-52. Again, I am indebted to Mr. Franz for these references.<br><br>

ck ambraseys methodological and 2009 for refs<br><br>

benMen91 <p>There was great destruction in Judea, Samaria,
and Galilee. Intensity at Jerusalem (A = 135 km) estimated
as MM 8; Io = 11; big earth slips in the Kidron
Valley, destruction of Razor, Sebastia (Mic. 1: 6) and
the ancient city of Kinnereth (9 km north of Tiberias).
A tsunami in the Sea of Galilee is hinted in Amos 5: 8;
9: 5-6.</p>

Am09 - [7] ‘. . . the posts of the temple moved when the Lord spoke . . .’ (2 Chron., XXVI. 16–17; 2 Kings XV.1–7).<br><br>


<br><br>
Am09 - There remains the question of whether there is any evidence today for active faulting in the immediate vicinity of Old Jerusalem that can be associated with the
ground deformations mentioned by Zechariah, Josephus and Nathan. Old aerial photographs of the chalky geological formations of the region show only landslides on steep
slopes, but no through-going faults. A relatively large slide can be recognised on the Mount of Olives, which is located on the slope which faces west towards the Old City,
the scarp of which can be seen halfway up the Mount of Olives. However, according to the Geological Survey of Israel, it is probably much more ancient than Biblical
times (Wachs and Lewitte 1984; Frydman 1997). The multitude of short scarps shown on relatively recent geological maps of Jerusalem all terminate at the Kidron Valley (Gil 1996).
The exception is a short northeast– southwest-running fault trace, which is shown on the Geotechnical Map of Jerusalem (Israeli 1977), which the Atlas of Israel labels
Zechariah 14:4, earthquake fault. This feature extends from a point a few hundred metres south of the Jerusalem Railway Station to the west, running for more than three
kilometres, to just north of al-Ayzariyah to the east, striking about N–70◦ E (Atlas of Israel 1985). The reason why this feature has been associated with Zechariah’s earthquake is not given.<br><br>
Am09 - Amos’ earthquake may be dated vaguely from the line of Jewish kings chronicled in the Old Testament, which provides us with 756 or 759 BC as a terminus ante quem (Soggin 1970, 120),
or perhaps earlier. Courville dates this earthquake to 751–750 BC, on the basis of the Jewish legend reported by Josephus in which the prophet Zechariah is quoted as a source indicating the
severity of the earthquake. This, however, would be the correct date only if the earthquake could be associated with the judgement on Uzziah, that is, only if Josephus’ account that the
earthquake occurred at the same time as Uzziah was stricken with leprosy could be proven to be true [6]. While the Zechariah quotation is suggestive, it does not specifically associate
the earthquake with God’s judgement on the king, and we cannot follow either Josephus’ or Courville’s attempts at a correlation without further evidence (Courville 1971, ii, 122). For
instance, Courville goes on to correlate Uzziah’s earthquake with other catastrophic events, such as, for instance, the eruption of Thera. He can do this only because he brings the
Late Bronze age down to the time of Uzziah, a view that must be rejected (Crisler 2004). If Courville’s view is adopted, however, the placement of Uzziah’s earthquake at the end of
Samaria II can be correlated with a wave of destructions at this stratigraphic level, destruction that is said to have affected the Holy Land and could also have been due to the
invasion by the Egyptians.<br><br>

Am09 - This earthquake happened probably somewhere E of Jerusalem, most likely along the Jericho fault. Apparently, the offset of the rocks across it was great enough to reveal
the northward slip of the eastern side relative to the southward slip of the western side. This motion is remarkably similar to the motion observed in the 1927 Jericho earthquake,
and is, of course, consistent with the N–S movement of the plates in this area’ (Nur and Ron 1996, 81). need to find Nur and Ron <br><br>



ANTONOPOULOS (1979) lists a tsunami hitting Coasts of Lebanon. Sur (Tyre) with m = VI<br><br>

Sources are<br><br>

AMBRASEYS N., 1962 - Data for the investigation of the seismic seawaves in the Eastern Mediterranean. Bull. Seism. Soc. Am., , 52, No. 4, pp. 895-913, October.<br><br>

SIEBERG A., 1932 - Untersuchungen Aber Erdbeben und Bruchschollenban im Astlichen Mittelmeergebiet.
Denkschriften der Medizinish-Naturwissenschaftlichen Gesellschaft zu Jena, vol. 2, Jena.<br><br>




</p>
</div>
</div>

<div id="JordanRiverDelta">Jordan River Delta</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1130/0091-7613(1994)022%3C0395:EFJEFS%3E2.3.CO;2">Niemi and Ben-Avraham (1994)</a> estimated that Event 2 was younger than 3-5 ka and older than 1927 CE.<br><br>

<h3 id="startTs">Tsunamogenic Evidence</h3>


<div style="padding:10px;">

<h3 id="startP">Paleoseismic Evidence</h3>

<table id="Paleo" class="wrappingarcheotable" style="width:100%; white-space:normal;">

<thead>
<tr>
<th>Location (with hotlink)</th>
<th>Status</th>
<th>Intensity</th>
<th>Notes</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><a href="#HacipasaTrenches">Hacipasa Trenches</a></td>
<td>possible to unlikely</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td>The oldest event identified in the Ziyaret Trench dated to before 983 CE. A lower bound on age was not available due to insufficient radiocarbon dates.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#KazzabTrench">Kazzab Trench</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td><a href="https://www.academia.edu/7836112/12_000YearLong_Record_of_10_to_13_Paleoearthquakes_on_the_Yammouneh_Fault_Levant_Fault_System_Lebanon">Daeron et al (2007)</a>
dated events S4, ?S5, and ?S6 to between 2115 and 6288 years B.P. These appear to be in Sequence 2 for which <q>the age-depth function</q> is unknown and a
hiatus was suspected.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#JarmaqTrench">Jarmaq Trench</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/222072723_Evidence_of_coseismic_ruptures_along_the_Roum_fault_%28Lebanon%29_a_possible_source_for_the_AD_1837_earthquake">
Nemer and Meghraoui (2006)</a> date Event Y to between 2920-2879 BCE and 84-239 CE.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#al-Harif">al-Harif Aqueduct</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/255983580_Timing_of_earthquake_ruptures_at_the_Al_Harif_Roman_Aqueduct_Dead_Sea_fault_Syria_from_archeoseismology_and_paleoseismology">Sbeinati et al (2010)</a>
dated Event W, characterized from paleoseismology (Trench C only), to between 3400-3000 BCE and 800-510 BCE and speculated that it may have been caused by the ~1365 BCE
earthquake which, they claim, affected Ugharit near Latakia in Northern Syria and Tyre in Southern Lebanon or another earthquake. They noted that
<q>the rate of sedimentation in unit f of trench C implies a minimum age of 962 B.C. for event W</q> and estimated ~4.6 m of slip.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Qiryat-Shemona">Qiryat-Shemona Rockfalls</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td></td>
<td><a href="https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.425.931">Kanari, M. (2008)</a> examined rockfalls in
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiryat_Shmona">Qiryat-Shemona</a> which were attributed to earthquakes.
Optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) dating was performed on soil samples beneath the fallen rocks.
Sample ID QS-13 was dated to 3.2 +/- 0.45 ka BP which makes one of the Amos Quakes a possible candidate
(<a href="https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.425.931">Kanari, 2008</a>).</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#BetZayda">Bet Zayda</a></td>
<td>no evidence</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td>Earthquakes before 392 BCE were not observed by <a href="https://www.tau.ac.il/~shmulikm/Publications/Wechsler-BSSA-2014.pdf">Wechsler et al (2014)</a> or
<a href="https://www.ipgp.fr/~klinger/web_Yann/papiers/wechsler_tectono18.pdf">Wechsler et al (2018)</a> however Tom Rockwell
(personal correspondence, 2022) indicates that several unstudied southern channels in the area could have captured older events such as one of the
Amos Quakes.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#TelRehov">Jordan Valley - Tel Rehov Trench</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td></td>
<td><abbr Title="Zilberman, E., Amit, R., Bruner, I., Nahmias, Y. (2004). Neotectonic and paleoseismic study : Bet She'an Valley. Jerusalem, Geological Survey of Israel.">
Zilberman et al (2004)</abbr> dated Event I to the 7th century BCE and Event II to the 6th century BCE.
Based on displacements, they estimated a Magnitude of 6.5-6.6 for Event I and 6.6-6.7 for Event II.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#TelSaidiyeh">Jordan Valley - Tell Saidiyeh and Ghor Kabed Trenches</a></td>
<td>no evidence</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/215605122_Episodic_behavior_of_the_Jordan_Valley_section_of_the_Dead_Sea_fault_from_a_14-kyr-long_integrated_catalogue_of_large_earthquakes">
Ferry et al (2011)</a> detected 12 surface rupturing seismic events in 4 trenches (T1-T4) in Tell Saidiyeh and Ghor Kabed; 10 of which were prehistoric.
They did not identify any paleoseismic events matching with the Amos Quakes and cited archaeoseismic evidence from other studies in Deir 'Alla
(Franken, 1989:204) and Tell Saidiyeh
(<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233647955_Tell_ES-SA_%27idiyeh_Preliminary_Report_on_the_First_Three_Seasons_of_Renewed_Excavations">Tubb, 1988:126-127, 130</a>)
for an earthquake from around this time.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#DeadSeaSeismiteTypes">Dead Sea - Seismite Types</a></td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#EnFeshka">Dead Sea - En Feshka</a></td>
<td>probable</td>
<td>8 - 8.8 (both seismites)</td>
<td>Two seismites are candidates (<a href="https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2010JB007452">Kagan et al, 2011</a>)
<ul>
<li>a 2 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 515 cm. depth with modeled Ages of 723 BCE ± 62 (1σ) and 731 BCE ± 124 (2σ)</li>
<li>a 2.5 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 521 cm. depth with modeled Ages of 821 BCE ± 65 (1σ) and 831 BCE ± 132 (2σ)</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#NahalDarga">Dead Sea - Nahal Darga</a></td>
<td>possible to probable</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td><a href="https://www.academia.edu/7922990/Holocene_Earthquakes_Inferred_from_a_Fan-Delta_Sequence_in_the_Dead_Sea_Graben">Enzel et. al. (2000)</a>
identified a 150 cm. thick seismite in coarse grained lithology in Deformed Unit 7 in Stratigraphic Unit 9 which dated to ~750 BCE
+/- 300 (~ 3000-2400 yrs BP).</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#EnGedi">Dead Sea - En Gedi</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td>8 - 8.9 (both seismites)</td>
<td>Two possible seismites from the En Gedi Core
(<a href="https://www.academia.edu/1052517/Recurrence_pattern_of_Holocene_earthquakes_along_the_Dead_Sea_transform_revealed_by_varve_counting_and_radiocarbon_dating_of_lacustrine_sediments">
Migowski et. al., 2004</a>)

<ul>
<li>a 2 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 351 cm. depth dated to ~700 BCE</li>
<li>a 5 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 355 cm. depth dated to 759 BCE</li>
</ul>
Dating appears to be based on radiocarbon rather than varve counting however there is a mis-match with the varve counting in this interval by
<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/291383773_Reconstructing_climate_from_the_Dead_Sea_sediment_record_using_high-resolution_micro-facies_analyses">
Neugebauer (2015)</a> and
<a href="https://www.academia.edu/14428645/Evidences_for_centennial_dry_periods_at_3300_and_2800_cal_yr_BP_from_micro_facies_analyses_of_the_Dead_Sea_sediments">
Neugebauer et al (2015)</a>.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#NahalZeelim">Dead Sea - Nahal Ze 'elim</a></td>
<td>probable</td>
<td>8 - 9 (both seismites)</td>
<td>Two possible seismites from <a href="https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2010JB007452">Kagan et al (2011)</a> at ZA-2.

<ul>
<li>a variable thickness brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 700 cm. depth with modeled Ages of 741 BCE ± 41 (1σ) and 746 BCE ± 79 (2σ)</li>
<li>a variable thickness brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 710 cm. depth with modeled Ages of 777 BCE ± 43 (1σ) and 783 BCE ± 78 (2σ)</li>
</ul>
The dual seismites at Nahal Ze'elim and En Feshka is what led <a href="https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2010JB007452">Kagan et al (2011)</a>
to hypothesize that the Amos Quakes were a pair of earthquakes (i.e. a couplet) thus explaining archaeoseismic evidence for this earthquake(s)
north and south of the Dead Sea.<br><br>

Jefferson Williams observed similar seismites in the East section of site ZA-4 above the Late Bronze Beach Ridge at (floating) depths of 577 cm.
(8 cm. thick) and 616 cm. (6-8 cm.thick).</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#ArabaIntro">Araba - Introduction</a></td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>n/a</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Taybeh">Araba - Taybeh Trench</a></td>
<td>possible to probable</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td>Event E8 in the Taybeh Trench (<a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-22627-9">LeFevre et al., 2018</a>)
was dated to 700 BCE +/- 186 and matches well with a ~750 BCE date for the Southern Amos Quake.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#Qatar">Araba - Qatar Trench</a></td>
<td>unlikely</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td><a href="https://academic.oup.com/gji/article/202/1/313/586642">Klinger et. al. (2015)</a> did not identify any events in the Qatar Trench
which correlate with either of the Amos Quakes.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#TabaSabhka">Araba - Taba Sabhka Trench</a></td>
<td>unlikely</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td>None of the events in the Taba Sabhka Trench correlate with an earthquake around the time of the Amos Quakes
(<a href="https://mospace.umsystem.edu/xmlui/handle/10355/43446">Allison, 2013</a>).</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#ShehoretAndRodedAlluvialFanTrenches">Araba - Shehoret, Roded, and Avrona Alluvial Fan Trenches</a></td>
<td>possible</td>
<td><abbr Title="assumed minimum local Intensity to cause ground rupture">≥ 7</abbr></td>
<td>Event 5, with 0.2 m of displacement, dated to 500 BCE +/- 1000 (1500 BCE - 500 CE).</td>
</tr>
</tbody>

<div id="HacipasaTrenches">Hacipasa Trenches</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>




The oldest event identified in the Ziyaret Trench dated to before 983 CE. A lower bound on age was not available due to insufficient radiocarbon dates.<br><br>

<div class="top expand">
<div id="KazzabTrench">Kazzab Trench</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>





<a href="https://www.academia.edu/7836112/12_000YearLong_Record_of_10_to_13_Paleoearthquakes_on_the_Yammouneh_Fault_Levant_Fault_System_Lebanon">Daeron et al (2007)</a>
dated events S4, ?S5, and ?S6 to between 2115 and 6288 years B.P. These appear to be in Sequence 2 for which <q>the age-depth function</q> is unknown and a
hiatus was suspected.<br><br>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="al-Harif">Displaced Aqueduct at al Harif, Syria</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>



<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/255983580_Timing_of_earthquake_ruptures_at_the_Al_Harif_Roman_Aqueduct_Dead_Sea_fault_Syria_from_archeoseismology_and_paleoseismology">Sbeinati et al (2010)</a>
dated Event W, characterized from paleoseismology (Trench C only), to between 3400-3000 BCE and 800-510 BCE and speculated that it may have been caused by the ~1365 BCE
earthquake which, they claim, affected Ugharit near Latakia in Northern Syria and Tyre in Southern Lebanon or another earthquake. They noted that
<q>the rate of sedimentation in unit f of trench C implies a minimum age of 962 B.C. for event W</q> and estimated ~4.6 m of slip.<br><br>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/al-Harif.html"
height="2000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="al-Harif"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="Qiryat-Shemona">Qiryat-Shemona Rockfalls</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>


<a href="https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.425.931">Kanari, M. (2008)</a> examined rockfalls in
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiryat_Shmona">Qiryat-Shemona</a> which were attributed to earthquakes.
Optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) dating was performed on soil samples beneath the fallen rocks.
Sample ID QS-13 was dated to 3.2 +/- 0.45 ka BP which makes one of the Amos Quakes a possible candidate
(<a href="https://nhess.copernicus.org/articles/19/889/2019/nhess-19-889-2019.pdf">Kanari et al, 2019</a>).<br><br>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/Qiryat-Shemona.html"
height="1800" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="Qiryat-Shemona"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="BetZayda">Bet Zayda (aka Beteiha)</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>


Earthquakes before 392 BCE were not observed by <a href="https://www.tau.ac.il/~shmulikm/Publications/Wechsler-BSSA-2014.pdf">Wechsler et al (2014)</a> or
<a href="https://www.ipgp.fr/~klinger/web_Yann/papiers/wechsler_tectono18.pdf">Wechsler et al (2018)</a> however Tom Rockwell
(personal correspondence, 2022) indicates that several unstudied southern channels in the area could have captured older events such as one of the
Amos Quakes.<br><br>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/BetZayda.html"
height="3000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="BetZayda"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="TelRehov">Jordan Valley - Tel Rehov Trench</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>


<abbr Title="Zilberman, E., Amit, R., Bruner, I., Nahmias, Y. (2004). Neotectonic and paleoseismic study : Bet She'an Valley. Jerusalem, Geological Survey of Israel.">
Zilberman et al (2004)</abbr> dated Event I to the 7th century BCE and Event II to the 6th century BCE.
Based on displacements, they estimated a Magnitude of 6.5-6.6 for Event I and 6.6-6.7 for Event II.<br><br>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/TelRehov.html"
height="2000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="TelRehov"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="TelSaidiyeh">Jordan Valley - Tell Saidiyeh and Ghor Kabed Trenches</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>



<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/215605122_Episodic_behavior_of_the_Jordan_Valley_section_of_the_Dead_Sea_fault_from_a_14-kyr-long_integrated_catalogue_of_large_earthquakes">
Ferry et al (2011)</a> detected 12 surface rupturing seismic events in 4 trenches (T1-T4) in Tell Saidiyeh and Ghor Kabed; 10 of which were prehistoric.
They did not identify any paleoseismic events matching with the Amos Quakes and cited archaeoseismic evidence from other studies in Deir 'Alla
(Franken, 1989:204) and Tell Saidiyeh
(<a href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233647955_Tell_ES-SA_%27idiyeh_Preliminary_Report_on_the_First_Three_Seasons_of_Renewed_Excavations">Tubb, 1988:126-127, 130</a>)
for an earthquake from around this time.<br><br>



<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/TelSaidiyeh.html"
height="2500" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="TelSaidiyeh"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="DeadSeaSeismiteTypes">Dead Sea - Seismite Types</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/DeadSeaSeismiteTypes.html"
height="1200" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="DeadSeaSeismiteTypes"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="EnFeshka">Dead Sea - En Feshka</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>



Two possible seismites from <a href="https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2010JB007452">Kagan et al (2011)</a>.

<ul>
<li>a 2 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 515 cm. depth with modeled Ages of 723 BCE ± 62 (1σ) and 731 BCE ± 124 (2σ)</li>
<li>a 2.5 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 521 cm. depth with modeled Ages of 821 BCE ± 65 (1σ) and 831 BCE ± 132 (2σ)</li>
</ul>


<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/EnFeshka.html"
height="1800" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="EnFeshka"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="NahalDarga">Dead Sea - Nahal Darga</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

<a href="https://www.academia.edu/7922990/Holocene_Earthquakes_Inferred_from_a_Fan-Delta_Sequence_in_the_Dead_Sea_Graben">Enzel et. al. (2000)</a>
identified a 150 cm. thick seismite in coarse grained lithology in Deformed Unit 7 in Stratigraphic Unit 9 which dated to ~750 BCE
+/- 300 (~ 3000-2400 yrs BP).<br><br>

<iframe src="https://deadseaquake.info/EarthquakeCatalogOfTheDeadSea/Sites/Geo/NahalDarga.html"
height="3000" width= "100%" allowfulllscreen = "true" style="border:none; chrome=false;" title="NahalDarga"></iframe><br><br>

</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cPanelWide">

<div class="top expand">
<div id="EnGedi">Dead Sea - En Gedi</div>
</div>

<div class="slidepanelWide">
<p>

Two possible seismites from the En Gedi Core
(<a href="https://www.academia.edu/1052517/Recurrence_pattern_of_Holocene_earthquakes_along_the_Dead_Sea_transform_revealed_by_varve_counting_and_radiocarbon_dating_of_lacustrine_sediments">
Migowski et. al., 2004</a>)

<ul>
<li>a 2 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 351 cm. depth dated to ~700 BCE</li>
<li>a 5 cm. thick brecciated (Type 4) seismite at 355 cm. depth dated to 759 BCE</li>
</ul>
